39201624.review:
I only have 1 gripe about this game and everything else is straight-up praise. It's just overly complicated, but luckily it's pretty gradual so you won't be lost at all trying to figure out what's what. It's just much wordier than it has to be if that makes any sense. If that's a statement that scares you off, don't let it. It's a great game and while it may take a couple rounds to truly begin to figure everything out, you'll be hooked once you do.

I found the original when it was a free game on some Flash game website a while back. Most of those Flash era games are glorified timewasters but the original GemCraft was on a totally different level. I was more than happy to shell out $10 for this after loving the original and I wasn't let down. There's some more depth to this sequel but it ramps it up pretty slowly so it's not cumbersome.

If you're on the fence and you enjoy TD games, this is definitely worth your money. If you want to try it out I'm sure you can still find the flash version elsewhere and play for free to see how you like it.

39070966.review:
An RPG light strategy tower defense game? Yes, yes, and yes. This is a massive game with outstanding replayability, hundreds of achievements, and many choices. You will lose over and over again until you master it. 

This is an incredibly deep and addictive game and it gives you new items and abilities slowly. You receive shadow cores to spend on abilities, but spend too many shadow cores and your starting mana is lower, making it harder to start each level. The gems you use can either be used by themselves and upgraded or can be combined with any type and number of other gems. The gems are all different, like poison, increased hit or critical hit chance, decreased armour, decreased healing, etc. You can also build walls and use gems in traps. One main strategy is to build fewer towers with stronger gems and traps with gems. Use your bolts and beams wisely as they take time to recharge. You can throw gem bombs.

Seeing fast enemies and giants can make you panic. You don't want them to reach your orb. Just build a combination of towers and traps and make sure you use poison a lot. Keep upgrading gems as you go and make sure you put them at strategic points. Walls can also help a lot if you make your enemies travel as far as possible so the gems can do their damage.

I keep coming back to play more of this game because it is such a fun, challenging, and massive game. Achievement hunters will love it. If you like tower defense games or just a good challenge, play this game. It is one of the few best of its type.

9.5/10

38807052.review:
Surprisingly deep 2D tower defense game, heavily favoring strategy and core gamers.

Really, it's quite deep. There's a lot of different ways to kill the monsters, and so much strategy you will learn and develop. It can be easy to get started, but you will eventually reach a point where you need to understand what's happening, strategize more deeply, and think hard about what to place where, when to enter certain levels, and what skills to have active for which field.

I'm not sure I will ever reach the higher levels, and instead I tend to play the same few fields that I enjoy over and over. For the casual gamer, this might be a compromise if you're bogged down in the strategy overload.

I especially appreciate the ability to build walls to redirect monsters - in a way I end up designing my own field, if I really use a lot of them.

Overall really excellent, and will give you anything you'd want in a tower defense game.

36892310.review:
GemCraft is a Tower Defense game, with a twist...

You combine different gem types to customize your towers and traps, which you place yourself.
Skills increase the power of your gems and spells. Each map contributes to your XP, best score from each.
In traditional RPG style, more XP=higher character level, giving more skill points to spend.
You can reset your skills if you want to, so you don't have to restart the game to try a different strategy.

There are too many maps (tracks) for me to count and you unlock 3 difficulty levels.
Each level can be played in "Endurance mode", which will max at 999 waves. (I think)
I've only made it to wave 260 or so.

This means that it will take a LONG time to fully complete this game. I have >480 hours in game and I can not see the light at the end of the tunnel. The replay value this game possesses is enormous. But it doesn't feel that way because of all the different maps.
This is why I have nominated this game for the write in category of "Best Replay Value."

"One More Round." 

This is, by far, one of the most addictive games I have played.  Whether in earlier Flash incranations or now as a standalone Steam game, I can lose an entire day just by loading it up.

Gemcraft is classic tower devence.  Place crystals into towers to fire at enemies, causing damage and slight status effects.  Place crystals in traps for focused status effects.  Upgrade, upgrade, upgrade, go back and beat your high scores so that you can upgrade some more.  

Simple concept, challenging execution, and more than a little addictive.

I searched for this game because I had played the original two Gemcraft games a long time ago and wondered if they were here. I was pleased to find this sequel, which takes the Gemcraft system and expands it in innovative and exciting ways without changing the core mechanic that works so well.

This game is my favorite tower defense. It's loaded with achievements, but they're not trivial to accomplish. There are many areas in which to progress through the game, and plenty of ways to make the levels more challenging. I also appreciate that the game doesn't hinge on upgrade trees for towers and traps, which might seem like an oversight but there are other more interesting choices to focus on as a result. This means you don't need to build an array of differentiated towers in every level (or in some cases, rely on towers at all).

I highly recommend this game. I've only put about nine hours in so far, but it's everything I hoped for and more. This game is worth every penny.

36396283.review:
I used to play a predecessor on some flash site a decade ago and had only vague fond memories. Boy am I glad, this game hasn't disappointed my memories of GemCraft - it's freaking awesome!

The main game consists of 168 pre-made maps. Monster spawns and paths are pre-set, while you generally build towers and sometimes mazes. The towers only serve as sockets for gems, which is where the game is starting to open up. There are 9 colours with different base stats and special effects and it is completely up to you how you combine and level up gems. Do you want slow-down, poison and armour tearing in a single gem? You can do that!

Meanwhile each beaten level causes you to get stronger and stronger both via the XP and skill system and via picked-up talisman fragments. You discover new gem colours and 6 different spells (e.g. freezing), adding a dynamic component to what otherwise might be relatively passive levels.

The progression is where this game really shines. If a monster with 1.000 HP seems unbeatable at first, after a few dozen hours monsters with trillions of HP will be trivial to kill. And the most astonishing thing is, the game always keeps up with your power level. After unlocking them, you have available 3 difficulties and 9 different "traits" to enhance each level and after the base level you can always enter Endurance Mode up to wave 999. With the wrong settings you can go back to level 1 and find yourself utterly out-classed. With the right settings and tactics you can go back to level 1 and upgrade your score from 100 XP to 100 billion XP, feeding back into growing stronger.

Personally I really enjoyed the ridiculous exponential levelling, culminating in beating my first Endurance Mode against a final "e45" wave, meaning its monsters' HP were numbers with 46 digits (aka a quattuordecillion). But at this point you are running into severe technical problems. With around 10.000 monsters on screen, my game grinds to a near-halt with less than 1 FPS. So even after 140 hours there is still much content left, but it's super grindy and little fun to stare at a slide-show for hours.

If all that power grind is not for you - don't worry! Grinding makes the game much much easier, but it is not required at all. And if you never crank up the difficulty, the game is actually pretty casual and relaxing. There are 23 "Vision Fields", that fully turn the genre around into a puzzle game. Here your progression doesn't matter as you have to beat challenges with pre-defined tools. This is taken to the extreme in Iron Wizard Mode, where you can run through the 168 levels of the base-game with a capped progression and no possibility to grind. After 80 hours in the main game, Iron Wizard Mode was still a really interesting challenge and made me think about the game in a different way, because overpowering brute force wasn't an option anymore.

There is just so much to do! Discovering 191 different maps, trying out new skill combinations and strategies, revisiting old levels with new challenges, etc! Many levels even feature interesting achievements, requiring you to think and play outside of your comfort zone (e.g. using only poison or building no towers). There is a very flimsy story arc with nice artwork, but don't expect a proper narrative. The graphics are decent, as is the sound. But let's be honest, the focus is clearly on gameplay first and foremost and this is where the game excels.

This is easily the best Tower Defense game out there and worth every penny! I have never seen such a variety and depth in a Tower Defense game with such a rock solid core gameplay. If you are still on the fence, try out the free browser-based flash version before buying.

164 stages of repetition. That's not good.

It does have some redeeming features. For example the targeting system is pretty nice. It could be better, with some options to combine the parameters. For example targeting the giant with lowest hp would be nice in some cases.

Basically it's the ultimate grindfest, but the problem is that it keeps on repeating itself. There's only 3 types of monsters and 9 different towers. The problem is that in most maps your tower options are severely limited. Usually you get to build 3-5 different types of towers. You can combine the types, theoretically increasing the amount of different towers to dozens, but it has its downsides and doesn't really add variety.

One other problem with the game is how its mechanics works. Basically all monsters heal and all monsters have armour. This means that in your first tower cluster you need towers that rip the monsters armour and in the second cluster the towers which you want to do the killing. There's yet one another problem how you deal damage with towers in this game. I also don't like how the support towers function and how the focus is to build one super high level damage tower since the building space is limited on most levels.

After reaching wizard level high enough in the normal game you need to manually increase the difficulty of each wave, which becomes extremely tedious as well.

The numbers also become extreme. I've seen monsters with xxxx * 10^21 hp and built towers which do xxxx * 10^18 and 80% chance to do * 9000000 more dmg. It's whack.

36145389.review:
You know, i got all the in-game achievements with just one steam achievement missing. Considering i spent 140 hours (-10 hours afk) and my achievement count still shows up as 100% (418/419) i will call this game done for now.

-

Gemcraft is an awesome and iconic 2D Tower Defense Game with an abundant choice of upgrades and difficulty options that you can change easily between 150+ levels. It got a unique and mystical story that i really got into while playing the game but that's not necessary to pay attention to, if you just want to progress in the game. The art and setting are really fitting as well.

If you're looking for a 2D Tower Defense Game, there are a few things you can expect right away, like different difficulties for different maps, an arsenal of different towers ranging from standard to unique towers all having a place and use case in the game, replayability and upgrades!

In my opinions Gemcraft exceeds in all of the listed points. You get more maps than you asked for but just enough to feed your endless craving for more, you get an extensive unlockable difficulty system to revisit beaten maps, you get levels out the oven to feed an immense scaling system with skill points and there are easter eggs and details left and right. You really feel how much thought was put into this game.

The tower system uses 9 different gems which incorporate skill effects corresponding to their color and you can mix and match them to your strategical needs. You drop the gems in the tower and upgrade them as you go. You can switch them out too, put them in traps, amplifiers or shrines. There is really a whole lot going on.

If you look for a tower defense game or if you're interested after reading this review you won't be disappointed by spending a few bucks.

Notes / Personal Milestones:
- Beat the storyline after 50 hours
- Reached level 1000 after 70 hours
- After 100 hours i reached level 1800, unlocked 98% of the achievements and finished 85% of the maps on a 70x difficulty multiplier
- 115 hours / lvl 2000 / 99% achievements (6 to go) / 90% maps
- After that i just finished the missing maps on hard mode without additional difficulty, started a new run for the last achievement but ultimately the grind grinded my gears and now i'm happy to let this game go, i got a little burnt out chasing achievements :')

I think there are many stages in the game and you have to decide for yourself how much time you want to invest into it. There are probably more casual players who wouldn't have the nerves to finish the storyline but get 20+ hours entertainment out of the game before they feel the repitition kicking in, then there are people who grind another 50 hours for high difficulty in every map, or maybe you want to grind all the 419 achievements. 

That said, in the late-late-stage of the game, you can learn how to do some real funky sh't with your gems to create "supergems", as i call them, and i'm with 2000+ levels at the stage where i could learn that, but i'm honestly done for now. It's just remarkable what you can do with this game though. The most popular guide for this game starts at lvl 2000+ but aims for people at lvl 5000+ too.

I can whole-heartedly recommend this game for anyone somewhat interested in Tower Defense Games for all the reasons i listed above and more (i definitely forgot some things), the only downside is the repetitive aspect found in many TD Games, but some people actually want that. I'd say you get easily 30 hours of gameplay experience out of Gemcraft without feeling the repetition too much. The game got a great way to unlock features and you'll be improving and changing up your playstyle frequently (if you want to) until you hit the "optimal setup".

Love the game, recommend the game, i'm donezo. Hope that got you interested, Bye!

35857723.review:
Probably the best tower defense game on Steam.

It's simple (and honestly, a bit easy unless you stack the modifiers to make it harder) but that's part of what makes it so great.

The gem aesthetic is pretty cool, as is the concept of mixing different colors.

Possibly the most best thing about it is all the different upgrades, skills, difficulty modifiers, challenges and achievements.  There's always something to do, unlock or improve.

I also like that it isn't one of those silly "you have to make your own maze out of towers" or "competitive TD" games.

My only criticism is that all of the towers feel pretty similar other than their color properties.  IE - the range, damage and attack speed of all colors are basically the same, and you can't "specialise" a tower.

Being able to make a long range, slow-shooting, hard hitting sniper tower -- or a short-range, fast-shooting machinegun to pick off weakened enemies -- would add a lot to the game's diversity.

All in all, this is a 9/10 game by TD standards.

35260063.review:
One of the few truly great TD games on Steam that's also *pure* TD instead of some sort of genre hybrid.

Instead of placing towers as you would in other TD games, Gemcraft's towers don't do anything on their own. They have an empty  slot that holds a gem, and the gem dictates what the tower does. The gems themselves don't have much pizzazz, only 9 in total and when placed in a tower they all look and behave very similarly except for color. Similar range, damage, etc. with some modifiers. (Slow, chaining, steals currency,...) The gimmick is that you can combine gems to mix their effects. They don't generate new effects (see the super cool Android game Myth Defense to see what that's like) but that makes them easier to understand, which can be good because the game has a lot going on at any given moment. 

Resource management, tower placement, path shaping, are all there, but there's many small systems on top that make the game as a whole remarkably complex. The uses for gems are the biggest contributor - aside from using gems for towers and floor-based "traps" (alternate tower essentially) you can also use gems as bombs, permanently destroying them instead of slotting them into a tower. You can also bomb the UI icon for an upcoming wave of enemies to "enrage" the wave and make it more difficult, increasing the number of enemies and their health and armor. Additionally, each tower has a handful of AI settings as well to fine-tune your monster-killing apparatus.

Outside of the moment-to-moment action, the game is most comparable to Dungeon Warfare due to (1) the ability to use modifiers to make the game intentionally harder so that you can get more XP from a stage, (2) having XP level the player up, and (3) having levels translate to skill points that you allot on various abilities before entering battle. The skills are more varied than DW though, and the penalties you can apply to yourself are in many cases more impactful. On top of this are a couple of interwoven systems of acquiring and leveling up collectible items that augment your game, something rarely seen in TD games and a welcome layer of complexity here. These systems make it so the strategy outside the game, before you even enter a stage, are a game unto themselves.

All in all easily worth $20 so a total steal at the usual $10 and a no-brainer when it's on sale.

Compared to other pure TD games I've played on Steam, it sits alongside Defense Grid, Dungeon Warfare, Defender's Quest, Creeper World 3, and Super Sanctum TD as games that are more than worth their money.

35258027.review:
GemCraft - Chasing Shadows ist ein Musterbeispiel für Spielmechaniken, die kinderleicht (und mit minimalem Tutorial) zu erlernen sind, aber auch schnell extrem schwer werden können. 

Das Grundprinzip ist einfach: Man hat verschiedene Edelsteine, die man in Türme packt und die dann auf Monster schießen. Die Komplexität kommt dann dadurch zustande, dass es neun verschiedene Arten von Edelsteinen gibt, die man weiter upgraden und kombinieren kann, in dem Levelsystem, womit man durch XP in Fähigkeiten investieren kann die einem im Spiel helfen, und durch die immer brutaler werdenden Monster [spoiler] von denen das fieseste auch im Pause-Modus weiter agieren kann [/spoiler] . Man kann auch durch den Talisman seine Kampfbedingungen beeinflussen (z.B. bestimmten Monstern mehr Schaden zufügen, Fähigkeiten schneller aufladen oder mehr XP bekommen) und das Spiel nach eigenem Gusto schwerer machen. 

Je schwerer man sich ein Level einstellt, desto mehr XP bekommt man natürlich, und das beste daran ist meiner Meinung nach wie viel Freiheit man dabei hat. Man kann zum Beispiel wenn man zusätzliche Monster hinzufügt nur Giganten beigeben, oder die Wellen schneller kommen lassen. Je nachdem wie schwer man es sich machen möchte kann man erstmal alle Felder ohne zusätzliche Monster oder Behinderungen aufdecken (wie eine Art Story Mode) oder gleich Hardcore an alles rangehen und sich dafür mit einer echten Challenge und vielen XP belohnen lassen. Da man das von Level zu Level entscheiden kann muss man sich auf nichts festlegen, und außer Zeit ist auch nichts verloren wenn man ein Level mal nicht schafft. 

Zu sehr sollte man sich aber nicht auf seine Fähigkeiten und Verbesserungen verlassen, denn es gibt optionale Felder bei denen man diese nicht mit ins Level nimmt. Dort kommt es allein auf die Strategie und das Timing an, und diese sind meiner Meinung nach brutal schwer und ich habe schon so einige zähneknirschende Stunden mit ihnen verbracht. Das ist aber nichts im Vergleich zu dem Triumph, die Nuss endlich geknackt zu haben!

Der Preis von 10€ ist es auf jeden Fall Wert, dieses Schmuckstück in seiner Bibliothek zu haben und sich hin und wieder dran zu setzen. Es ist toll sich an einem verregneten Tag zu einem guten Hörbuch und einer Tasse Tee vor dieses Spiel zu setzen und ein paar Stunden lang auf Monster zu schießen. Da ich selbst kein großer Fan von expliziter Gewalt bin gefällt mir das Design gut, das die düstere Stimmung perfekt rüberbringt, ohne auf realistische Gewalt zurückgreifen zu müssen. 

Ein perfektes Spiel für zwischendurch wegen des leicht zu verstehenden Systems und des frei verstellbaren Schwierigkeitsgrades und für die ganz harten mit beinahe unmöglichen Schwierigkeiten und Endlosmodus für jedes Level, nachdem man es geschafft hat (dabei werden die Wellen immer stärker, aber man kann weiter XP farmen). Nicht zuletzt auch für Unerfahrene im Genre (wie mich :D) ein fantastisches Spiel.

10/10 Kaufempfehlung!

35130706.review:
GemCraft is a tower defense - strategy game. Your aim is to defend your main base with gems from waves of enemies. There are nine types of gems like critical hit gem, poison gem, etc and you can combine your gems. To use these gems, first of all you need to make a tower. All of these costs mana and you gain mana from slaying beasts.

Gameplay is also fun, if you don’t want to wait that much at a level, you can press the 3x speed button. Also, if you count on your defense, you can spawn other waves of enemies at once.

Level designs are good, so you never get bored and feel like you’re playing the same thing over and over again. Moreover, there is a skill system where you can spend your points gained from leveling up.

All in all, i think it’s a must-buy if you love Tower Defense games. Even if you’re not, take a look at it.

I also reviewed it on my Curator Page, i'd be grateful if you could take a look at it and follow. http://steamcommunity.com/groups/akusarireview#curation

35091838.review:
I haven't played a ton of this yet, but it is a really nice tower defense that has some interesting upgrade mechanics around the towers.  You get gems, and have to build them up to be more powerful over the course of the level.  You then place the gems in towers to do damage.

Its a lot of fun.  There is some RPG elements as well, your main character gets to level up with weapons, and special powers as you hit certain levels in the game.

Update:

Have played quite a bit recently and really still enjoying the game.  I am a little lost at the storyline, not so much present...  And I am lost as to whether to replay the same levels at harder difficulty to level up or to keep pushing ahead.  Not a lot of help, just play how you want I suppose.  Still a really fun game that I am enjoying.

34433245.review:
Fantastisches Tower-Defense-Game mit jeder Menge Tiefgang und hohem Suchtpotentzal.

Positiv:

+ Innovative Spielmechanik durch die Verwendung von Edelsteinen, die man in die Türme einbaut.
+ Unzählige Möglichkeiten, Edelsteine in Türmen und Fallen zu kombinieren und zu leveln.
+ Interessantes Skill- und Talisman-System.
+ Enorme Anzahl an Level (fast schon zu umfangreich, siehe unten).
+ Viele verschiedene Strategien können zum Ziel führen.
+ Spannende Story.
+ Düstere Atmosphäre.
+ Der "Iron Wizard" Mode ist extrem spaßig und fordernd.
+ Stabiles Spiel, ich hatte in 100+ Stunden keinen einzigen Absturz.
+ Ideal für zwischendurch, da die Level relativ zügig abgeschlossen werden können (ca. 10 - 15 Minuten pro Level, sofern man nicht farmt, dann wird das ganze deutlich zeitaufwändiger und man kann mehrere Stunden in ein Level investieren).
+ Motivierende Achievements, die zudem durch einen Skillpunkt im Spiel belohnen. Gute Idee.

Negativ:

- Relativ wenige Arten von Gegnern (im Grunde nur drei, abgesehen von den seltenen, fliegenden Einheiten).
- Durch die hohe Anzahl an Level unterscheiden sich viele kaum voneinander. Im späteres Spielverlauf artet das etwas in "abarbeiten" aus.
- Die Stärke der Edelsteine lässst sich schnell nicht mehr durch den Spieler selbst berechnen. Wenn man verschiedene Farben kombiniert, wird es extrem kompliziert. Hierfür wird dann ein externes Programm benötigt (relevant allerdings nur bei Mana- und EXP-Farming, das Spiel lässt sich ansonsten auch ohne durchspielen). 
- Das Endgame besteht zum großen Teil aus Grinding (Mana- / EXP-Farming). Hier kommt dann meistens auch nur noch eine Strategie zum Einsatz (Mana-Falle, Kill-Tower), das wird schnell eintönig.
- Abruptes Ende (allerdings mit einem schönen Twist).
- Performance mangelhaft. Trotz extrem rudimentärer 2D-Grafik stockt das Spiel schnell, sollten viele Einheiten auf der Karte sein (und das geschieht im Endgame zwangsläufig). Der Lüfter meines Rechners hatte hier einiges zu tun ...

The definitive Tower Defense game.  It transcends the genre.  Anyone with a love of strategy games should give the next hundred hours of their game lives to this game.  You won't regret it.

I pray for the return of a sequel.

La progression devient malheureusement trop lente mid-game.

De plus, comme de nombreux TD, la prise d'XP est très faible si on rejoue un monde déjà passé. Vous prenez uniquement la différence d'XP par rapport à votre victoire précédente...

C'est très frustrant de perdre de justesse, vous perdez ainsi facilement 30 minutes de jeux sans rien en retour.

Les gemmes sont imposées pour "diversifier" l'expérience du joueur, mais à la fin, c'est juste chiant de ne pas pouvoir utiliser tous les outils ensembles.

Bref, si vous le recommande uniquement si vous êtes très patient.

33670464.review:
ดูเผิน ๆ เกมนี้คุณอาจจะคิดว่าเป็นเกม tower defense สำหรับสาย hardcore เพียว ๆ แต่เกมนี้จริง ๆ แล้วใคร ๆ ก็เล่นได้ครับ เพราะจุดเด่นของมันคือออกแบบมาให้คุณเล่นได้ตามสไตล์การเล่นของตัวเอง คุณอยากจะเล่นแบบ casual ชิล ๆ ปิดตาก็ยังผ่านก็ได้ หรือจะเล่นแบบยากสัส ๆ กดปุ่มช้าไปวินาทีเดียวก็ restart ได้เลย ก็ได้อีกเหมือนกัน

สิ่งที่ทำให้เกมนี้เล่นได้ตามสไตล์ของคุณก็คือเกมเปิดให้คุณฟาร์ม LV ของตัวคุณได้แบบไม่อั้น ยิ่ง LV เยอะคุณก็จะมีแต้ม skill ให้อัพเยอะ และแต้ม skill ที่ไม่ได้ใช้จะเพิ่มมานา (ที่เอาไว้สร้างป้อม) ตอนเริ่มเกมให้คุณอีกด้วย ดังนั้นถ้าคุณ LV สูงมาก ๆ  เริ่มเกมมาก็สามารถสร้างป้อมที่ยิงมอนทีเดียวจอดยันจบด่านได้เลย (ถ้าคุณยอมเสียเวลาฟาร์ม LV อ่ะนะ) นอกจากนี้เกมยังยอมให้คุณ enrage wave ของมอนสเตอร์ซึ่งจะทำให้มันมีจำนวนเยอะขึ้น แข็งแกร่งขึ้นได้แบบไม่จำกัดเช่นกัน ทำให้ถึงแม้จะคุณ over lv ไปสูงมาก ๆ ก็ยังสามารถเลือกที่จะส่งมอนสเตอร์ระดับเดียวกับคุณมาได้ ซึ่งก็จะทำให้ lv คุณเพิ่มสูงไปได้อีก (เพราะมอนเยอะก็หมายถึง XP เยอะ)

ตัวเกมเป็น tower defense แบบคลาสสิค หมายถึงคุณสามารถวางป้อมตรงไหนก็ได้ในแผนที่ และสามารถวางกำแพงเพื่อกำหนดทางเดินมอนสเตอร์ได้ ซึ่งในการวางป้อมเกมนี้จะเป็นป้อมเปล่า ๆ คุณต้องสร้าง gem ไปวางบนป้อมอีกที โดยจะมี gem 9 แบบให้คุณสร้าง แต่ละแบบก็จะมีพลังพิเศษแตกต่างกัน ซึ่งสามารถเอามาผสมกันได้ด้วย เช่น เอา poison gem ผสมกับ slow gem เป็น gem ที่ยิงใส่ศัตรูแล้วจะทำให้ศัตรูติดพิษและ slow ไปพร้อม ๆ กัน

ตัว gem ในเกมนี้สามารถอัพเกรดได้แบบไม่จำกัด ซึ่งก็จะใช้มานาในการอัพเกรดเยอะขึ้นเรื่อย ๆ ทีละ 2 เท่า และมันสามารถมี damage เป็นแสนล้านได้ หากคุณมีปัญญาหามานาอัพเกรดมันได้พอ ทำให้การวางป้อมในเกมนี้จะเน้นไปที่การวางป้อมหลักไม่กี่ป้อมเท่านั้น โดยจะอัพเกรด gem เรื่อย ๆ มากกว่าจะวางป้อมเพิ่ม

เกมมีระบบต่าง ๆ ค่อนข้างเยอะ คีย์ลัดมากมายที่ต้องใช้เวลาในการเรียนรู้ในระดับนึง เช่น กับดัก ป้อมเพิ่มพลัง การใช้ gem bomb การใช้ shrine เพื่อโจมตีศัตรูจำนวนมาก ฯลฯ แต่สิ่งที่สำคัญสุดที่คุณควรหัดใช้คือการ enrage wave มอนสเตอร์เพื่อเพิ่มจำนวนของมัน ซึ่งจะทำให้คุณอัพ LV ได้เยอะตามไปด้วย

ในเมื่อเกมสามารถฟาร์ม LV เพื่อเล่นแบบง่าย ๆ ได้ คุณอาจจะสงสัยว่าแล้วจะมีใครบ้าเล่นแบบยาก ๆ ใช่ไหมครับ เหตุผลหลักคือหากคุณสามารถ unlock skill สำคัญ ๆ จากการผ่านด่านต่าง ๆ ได้ครบแล้ว คุณจะสามารถฟาร์ม LV แบบโหดที่เล่นด่านเดียวได้ XP เป็นหมื่นล้าน อัพ LV ทีละเป็นร้อย LV ได้เลย นั่นทำให้หากคุณยอมเล่นแบบยาก ๆ ไม่ฟาร์ม LV เพื่อผ่านด่านให้ไวที่สุด เน้นไปที่การผ่านด่านเพื่อ unlock skill สำคัญ ๆ ให้ครบก่อน แล้วค่อยมาฟาร์ม LV ทีหลังทีเดียว มันจะประหยัดเวลาในการเล่นได้มากครับ

นอกจากนี้สำหรับสาย hardcore เกมก็มีโหมด iron wizard ที่จะไม่มี LV ให้อัพ คุณจะได้แต้ม skill point จากการผ่านด่าน ด่านละ 5 แต้มแค่นั้นเอาไว้ให้คุณเล่นด้วย ซึ่งขอบอกว่ามันยากและท้าทายสุด ๆ ไปเลย และหากคุณต้องการเก็บ achievement อันสุดท้าย คุณจำเป็นต้องเล่นโหมดนี้ให้จบอีกด้วยครับ

33535853.review:
Been a very addicting game, despite the intial difficulty in early progression. 
I will admit I was frustrated with certain parts of this game. The longer you play it the more rewarding a single game becomes. Like the previous flash games you start pretty small, and work your way to higher power. Once you're in the level 2,000+ range you probably have a pretty good strategy down. 
Vision fields are going to challange you, ecspecially if you don't use a guide. I'm still struggling to figure out how to beat some of them. 
If anyone is interested in playing this game, I highly recommend you check out GemCombiner, which is 3rd party. The way the number system in the game works, you can exploit how the gem combinations result. (Better combinations = better damage and effects.) It's not something you couldn't do on your own, but the software automatically combines up to thousands of gems for you without any effort. 
I started using the combiner about 1/4 of the way through the game, and it improved my experience by a landslide. 

All in all, the game is terrific as far as tower defense games go, probably the very pinnacle of tower defense. 
Again, it starts a little slow, but once you have put some hours in it will pay off!

It takes the components from the original and adds to them without making it overly complicated. There's seemingly hundreds of levels (I've only gotten to around 40~ of them, and I'm almost 17 hours into it) and there's different sort of "challenges" (i.e. things that make the level harder) that you can do to make replaying old levels fun and earn a ton of EXP. This game will keep you busy for hours if not days.

33395495.review:
There are three phases to this game:
1) Starting out, developing an understanding of game mechanics, and pushing through levels.
2) Coming to an understanding of what you're supposed to be doing, running around unlocking stuff, checking out guides and videos to figure out your broad objectives and how to most effectively reach them.
3) Mana farming for hours on end. (Seriously, you could potentially mana farm for like 10 hours straight of real time).

Each phase does have a lot of fun to it, but it's really too bad that manafarming is the end game, cause it is time consuming and serves only to mana farm better.

On sale, this game is a fun diversion that's worth the money.

33273883.review:
Saying GemCraft Chasing Shadows is a tower defense is like saying Garry's mod is a first-person shooter. Like, yeah, technically it is, but...
If anything, it's in many regards way more similar to old RPGs like Diablo where you'd set up skill points, gear, sockets, loot, and all of that stuff in order to kick ass and do a bunch of crazy stuff like chain hits that freeze enemies and leech mana while doing crit damage and whatever the hell.
Everything is put together very cleverly and in a way that lets the player experiment to their heart's content instead of limiting them with garbage caps and artificial difficulty. (Many skills have unlimited level caps, they just increase the point cost per level to balance it out)
I used to play the browser version but now I can finally play the Steam version to let everyone know I'm busy jerking off.

Biggest pro: Lets you get away with hilarious game-breaking combos if you're smart enough and try a lot of things. I've gotten to a point where enemies have broken numbers of hit points IE: 2.7781+e15 and I still one-shot them. (That eventually comes to bite you in the ass in endurance mode anyway so I guess it isn't that game-breaking)

Biggest con: Very VERY grindy. You technically have to do every field 3 times (there's hundreds of them) if you want to get your hands on every skillpoint you can get from them. Shadowcores used to be the game's freemium currency, but now they just drop normally in this version. (Albeit not enough in my opinion)

33247396.review:
One of the best tower defense games I've ever played. The system offers so much depth by having gems that give special abilities like a slow gem and chain hitting gem. You can combine gems together so if you put a slow gem with a chain gem, you'll now chain hit monsters with a slow effect. This gives you countless combinations for different strategies. As far as tower defense games goes, this is probably one of the best I've played. The original Defense Grid was pretty and the gameplay was entertaining but this one beats that for strategy and gameplay. Let's be clear, the graphics take a back seat to gameplay and challenge here. It's not that the game is "ugly" but the game is far from "pretty" too. Top down 2D with basic sprites for mobs and towers. Just want to get that out of the way. 

In every other way possible, this game is superior to other TD games. While the end-game is pretty cookie-cutter in how you design your defenses, early on you can get creative and just enjoy different ways to win each level. Admitedly, the game is a bit easy for the first 100-150 player levels but in order to unlock all the levels and get all the gems / challenges, it's quite the grind but in a good way. There are a wide vareity of level designs from the typical maze that is made for you and those you have to make yourself. Being able to power-up your gems and skills also adds a fun dynamic (although again for end-game it's very cookie cutter but that's not for everyone). 

I've put more than 100 hours into the game and I'm still not done. At player level 500, I have all but 2 or 3 maps completed (except the challenge maps) and all but 1 skill unlocked (red gem...I hate that level) but for those into TD games, this is a must have in your collection.

31519281.review:
Don't let the simple graphics fool you- This is a hugely in-depth Tower Defence game, with a vast variety of levels, potential towers & traps (activated by creating & merging the titular gems which define a Tower/Trap's properties), space for maze-building, and a whole lot more. 

You level up as a character in an approximately RPG style, allocating points to different skills, while finding different talismans and slotting them into a growing network that can give you powerful abilities. The plot is sparse, but it's there, and the map is vast, slowly revealing itself hex by hex as you spread out in different directions exploring it.

Possibly the best aspect is the sheer customizability- not just in terms of merging gems, but with the game difficulty as well. You earn level Traits which can be used to varying degrees each to change level difficulties in different ways, to gain more experience. Likewise, you can enrage oncoming waves over and over, rush them in early, or leave things as they are- You never feel penalised for playing 'too gently', and it gives you room to expand and push yourself on more axis than just "Easy" "Normal" "Hard" would (though there are difficulty levels on top of all this..!).

So, yes- If you're a Tower Defence fan, this is an insta-buy. If you're not, this may well be the game that makes you one.

31446745.review:
Gemcraft - Chasing Shadows represents tower defense game excellence.

It has wonderfully flexible gameplay through its gem combination systems and multiple leveling mechanics, allowing anyone to customize the experience to their own prefered style.  It quickly does an excellent job teaching you its basics, and then has fantastic replayability for revisiting the same early levels later as your experience grows.  That first level you barely cleared? You can play it again later when you return with enhanced gem abilities, and then you can choose yourself to make it still more difficult for further rewards.  It supports changing your abilities during the same game without restarting, and an engaging backstory that drives the missions forward without ever seeming like just another level.  How does the story end?  In a way, I hope it never does and the sequels continue!

Basicly speaking all you have to do is to attach the gems you're given for each stage into towers and traps and their effect varies depending of the gem level, type and where you use it and how you use it. GEM CRAFT IS THE DISGAEA OF TOWER DEFENSE (without the comedy by the way).

31068673.review:
This has become one of my favorite games, and I believe every tower defense fan has a good chance of really enjoying this game. Gemcraft - CS is based on the original Flash game (haven't played it at time of writing, but I should get around to it sooner or late). I've played a lot of Flash tower defense games, but Gemcraft is very unique, for many reasons:

[b]Gameplay & Mechanics:[/b] Is similar to other top-down TD games, in which your sole objective is to defend your base (in this case, your Orb) from hordes of enemies. You do this by placing gems into towers and traps. It's a simple premise, but the game incorporates so many elements that complicate matters. Every gem type has a different special effect, and many factors, such as the shape of the field, the gems you have available (you don't unlock all the gems for use on every map until later in the game), and the skills/abilities you have, just to name a few. You can also speed up time, which is very useful as things WILL get slow at times, or pause time entirely while you make decisions. This sounds broken, but I assure you, it isn't. You can even play in Iron Wizard mode, which disables most of the extra bonuses and makes the game more like a typical TD experience, with the difficulty being thrown at you head-on. Much of the game is the player investing more in their talisman bonuses and skill points to challenge more difficult maps and make more progress in endurance runs.

[b]Sound:[/b] Nothing too fancy, the music is ambient and fits the mood of the game, while the sounds do what they need to. Nothing I'd mind if they were muted, but not bad.

[b]Graphics:[/b] Same as the Sound department. Not bad at all, and the gems are pretty to look at, but nothing incredibly fancy. It looks exactly like a Flash game.

[b]Performance:[/b] The game runs very well overall, but there can be significant lag due to all the enemies and effects on the screen if you progress far enough in waves. A lot of people complain about this, but this is a very common, and often unavoidable problem in games. I have seen a couple of apparent fixes for this, but have yet to try them. However, it shouldn't be too hard to run this game decently.

[b]Replayability:[/b] When the store page tells you that this game has an emphasis on strategy and replayability, it is [i]not[/i] lying to you. There are dozens of maps to play and as you level up and discover new strategies, you can replay stages you've beaten to gain more XP and go for rarer talisman fragments to further power up, and you decide how much harder to make your endurance runs. All this adds to many hours of replaying, which makes the game grindy, but to me it rarely feels like just a monotonous grind because I enjoy seeing how much stronger I've become since the last time I played a particular map, and regardless if it is a new map or not, it's fun to me. In addition, there are hundreds of achivements, and while some are freebies, the majority require at least a bit of skill to obtain. Your level can soar into the thousands and there is a lot of complicated math with the game's inner workings, for those who like solving that stuff (too intimidating for me). There is a lot to do in this game for dedicated TD fans, but more casual players may prefer a simpler experience.

I love this game, and out of all the TD games I've played, this is one of the most unique I've played. If you're a longtime fan of the genre, you should give it a chance. You likely won't be disappointed.

[b]Pros:[/b]

- Simple gameplay at its core

- Many ways to customize your abilities and challenge level

- Many, many maps and achievements, offering immense replayability for a TD game; the desire to keep earning things can become addicting

[b]Cons:[/b]

- The many facets of micro-managing various gameplay elements may turn off those looking for a simpler experience

- This game is inherently grindy, especially with the randomization of talisman fragment drops and certain enemies that may or may not appear in a given run, so people who are bothered by grinding in games should probably stay away

- Some people like an immediate challenge, but this game is only as hard as you make it, which some may not prefer

30451602.review:
[b] Grindy, but entertaining tower defense that offers deep customization and many different tactics to complete the levels, boosting up the replay value a lot [/b]

Starts out a bit slow, and with really simple, linear levels. After a while you start receiving upgradable gemstones for your talisman that give you passive bonuses. They might be x% damage to a specific enemy type, faster tower reload rate, more mana, slower killchain decrease rate etc. That alone lets you build a "character" for a specific playstyle. 
But wait, there's more!
We have skills that also give passive bonuses, different tower types of course and combination of those tower types. You can either build a "pure" tower with one element, or a combination of 2 or more different types. So far i've been in levels that offered me 6 different types at the same time, and i could make a combination of all of them in the same tower. It costs a lot though! In addition to towers we have traps that are built on the ground for bad guys to walk over. Like towers, they can be equipped with one element, or a combination. We also have spells that give special attacks to your towers or traps. 

There are a lot of levels. Some of them are pure classic tower defense, some feature additional objectives like destroying a certain targets before the last wave, either by simply shooting them with your towers or using some specific spell/level gem to bomb them with. The design seemed first very linear, but after a while they started opening up, and we can build proper mazes on many levels! That's the most fun part of TD game in my eyes, and not many TD games offer us that, for some strange reason. After the waves you can start Endurance mode for more exp, enemies and talisman stones! If you want more challenge on the levels, you unlock battle traits when progressing in the game. They increase the exp in addition to the difficulty.

I haven't experienced a single bug, everything runs smooth.

[b] Shuold you buy it?[/b]

YES! Defense grid 1 has always been my favorite TD game, it offers everything a good TD game should. But i think this may replace DG on the number one spot! The amount of different playstyles this game offers is stunning.

30277382.review:
I've played a number of tower defense games over the years, but never seriously. I thought it was just a genre full of fairly generic, brief diversions. None of them seemed to be serious games. None had any real depth. After an hour, you'd seen everything the game had to offer.

With GemCraft - Chasing Shadows, that hour will give you just the briefest glimpse of what the game has to offer.

This game has so many fantastic and innovative concepts brilliantly intertwined that it's hard to even know where to begin to describe it. Just covering the individual features like the amazing trait system, which allows you to tune the difficulty for increased XP gains, or the deep skill system, which give you the ability to tweak the power level of every tool at your disposal each game, or the wide array of gems, each with unique characteristics and the ability to combine with others, will not come remotely close to doing the game justice.

GemCraft - Chasing Shadows combines all of these elements and many more in a seamless whole. Every single part of the game is smoothly intertwined with others. Leveling gives you skill points, which tweak your gems and spells, which define your towers and play style. All of this is impacted by fragments, allowing you to further tweak your build and play style. Even getting achievements is tied into the game by giving you skill points!

Even with everything I've said, so much was left uncovered. This game is crazy with content, all of which is fantastic. It even has an interesting story! This is not your usual tower defense game. It's the pinnacle of the genre. If you don't play this game, you are doing yourself a tremendous disservice. 

Buy this game.

30270930.review:
TDゲーム。
TDにレベルアップやスキルポイントでのビルド構築、タリスマンという装備アイテムドロップなどのハクスラ要素を加えたゲームだ。
「クリティカル率アップ」など固有の効果を持つ9種類のジェムの合成やアップグレードを行い、タワーやトラップにジェムを嵌めて敵を攻撃させたり、敵の上に直接ジェムを投下させてオーブを防衛していく。設置不可の箇所以外はタワーとトラップ、壁を自由に配置して敵の進行ルートをコントロールできる。特定のマップでは、ただ防衛するだけではない特殊なクリア条件が設定されているものがある。全部で200マップ近くありボリュームは十分だ。
タワーを乱立させるタイプのTDではなく、突き詰めれば1つのタワーを可能な限り強化していくものとなっている。なぜなら、Waveが進むごとの敵の強さの上昇が大きく、タワーをアップグレードしていくごとにアップグレードコストの上昇が大きいため、あまり多くタワーを乱立させていく余裕はなくなっていくからだ。

[ジェム合成]
複数のジェムを合成できるが、2つのジェムを合成したからといって"1+1=2"という単純なものにはならない。このため、合成していないピュアなジェムも活用できる余地がある。むしろピュアなジェムは強いくらいだ。

[ビルド]
マップをクリアしたり、レベルが上がるとスキルポイントが貰え、自由にスキルに割り振ることでビルドを構築できる。余ったスキルポイントは初期マナボーナスになるので、全てを割り振る必要はない。

[実績]
実績は多いが、大半は「○○して、○○しろ」のようなチャレンジ的な実績なので、自分で工夫して解除するのが好きなら苦にならない実績数だと思う。

[Iron Wizard Mode]
本編からレベルやタリスマンなどのハクスラ要素を省いたモードだ。要するに通常のTDに相当するもので、レベリングによるゴリ押しが効かないので難易度は高い。

幅広いカスタマイズ性をゲーム性に上手く結びつけたゲームバランスは素晴らしい。ジェムの合成配分、ビルド構築など単純なバランスにはなっていないので、プレイヤーが工夫する余地が大きくストラテジー性がある。また、リスクとリターンがは明確にされているので「ローリスクならローリターン」で「ハイリスクならハイリターン」なバランスだ。ハスクラ要素によるインフレ感での爽快感もある。
ただし、ゲーム後半からは効率的なレベル上げのために、敵の強化で難易度の調整して取得経験値を上げる必要があるので、シンプルさを求めている人には向かないのかもしれない。
TDとハクスラが好きで、自分で工夫して試行錯誤するのが好きならオススメなゲームだ。

29867632.review:
The GemCraft series changed my entire perspective on how a true Tower Defense game should be. Playing these games made Kingdom Rush and similar look so boring and dumb that I never even bothered with them.

GemCraft plays differently than other TDs. It starts out painfully easy, but as the game goes on you unlock various ways to make the game harder for yourself, increasing both difficulty and rewards. Endurance mode is the epitome of all this; most "infinite" modes are just that, infinite. GemCraft's ends at 999, and it's no cakewalk.

Here's generally how the game goes, from what I can tell:
- Early-game: Playing maps on easy, playing with difficulty as you unlock it, gaining skills/power
- Mid-game: Finishing up the remaining maps, going back to earlier maps and overloading them with difficulty modifiers to get lots of XP, completing challenge cheevos
- Late-game: Endurance runs
- Post-game: Trying to beat your high score on that max difficulty endurance run

Since GemCraft ends up being quite a different experience, I recommend playing this and its earlier titles online first (but not the first one, it's not as good). You can find them on Armor Games or Kongregate.

Also, Mac or Linux users: just because this game is Windows-only doesn't mean you can't play it! Just run Steam inside of Wine, install the game, and you should be good to go! (Disclaimer: Not all games work that well with Wine. This one just happens to be one of the good ones. Look up your game first to see if others have tested it!)

29797211.review:
Gemcraft is by far the best tower defense game/series I've ever played, even better than Bloons, and Chasing Shadows continues that streak. Gemcraft - Chasing Shadows maintains, with modifications and additions, its great mechanics and eye-catching graphics. There are a lot of levels to try to beat your previous score (sometimes by several million points), and in the addiction of leveling up your skills you can easily clock over 100 hours into the game - and you don't even have to be paying attentions! You can just run the game in the background or a small window while you do something else and check back every so often. That's how I reached 175 hours, and I could keep going.

The one bad thing about the game is that during endurance runs, which can go for quite a long time, the game starts slowing down to unbearable levels. I think I've read that this is because the game if Flash-based, and Flash can't handle large loads of objects. Hopefully, the developers will port the next game in the series to Steam in something other than Flash, or whatever causes the obnoxious slow down. This would easily cut the length of endurance runs by half.

29511133.review:
This is probably the best tower defense game I have played in recent memory. It's signature system of combining gems (the towers are gems) allows for an amazing number of possible strategies. But despite the amazing complexity, it is very well balanced.

I must expand on the gem combining. You have red gems with chain-hits, and yellow gems with critical-hits. You can merge the two gems into a single tower with critical-chain-hits to pump out massive DPS. Maybe combine a green poison gem with a purple armor-tearing gem. Set it up near the start to weaken enemies before they get to your damage dealing towers.

Additionally, this is basically the only tower defense game that has not been "solved" as far as I am aware. People are still debating of what strategies are the most effective, which also demonstrates the popularity of this game within the genre.

29418329.review:
It's not thaaat bad, I do understand why it's so popular. Still, I can't recommend it, and here come the reasons: 

- It's just too easy, really. In the 10+ levels I have played so far I have been in trouble just once. There _are_ higher difficulty options, but you have to _unlock_ them through grinding for countless, boring hours. 
- The active-pause doesn't make this better. Using active-pause in a tower defense is just breaking the game. 
- The leveling up is ridiculous. Not only do you get xp for things like "Select an enemy" or "Place a wall", i.e. just for _anything_, but almost all skills are just passive boons not altering the gameplay in any way. 
- Also, while there are many different types of gems, their effects don't differ _that_ much actually. It really doesn't matter if you do extra damage by having a chance of "critical hit" or a chance of "chain hit". 
- While combining the gems does stack effects in synergistic ways, those synergies are ways too obvious, making everything even more simple. 

So, if you want an epic time sink and some _very_ shallow sence of achievement, or are just a die-hard fan of the genre, you might have fun with gemcraft. For me, it is more like cigarettes: just not enjoyable at the beginning, addictive yet still not enjoyable later on.

29097314.review:
GemCraft - Chasing Shadows is the metaphorical hidden "gem" among indie tower defence games. You play as a sorcerer who uses magical gems to protect his "orb of presence" (the command centre or flag, if you will) from waves of monsters. This Fantasy theme was what made me buy this game in the first place, and I did not regret it.

In comparison to other TD games I have played, the gems used in towers and traps have a particularly wide variety of effects, including but not limited to single target or multiple target damage, damage over time, slowing down, armor piercing, mana leeching (mana is the currency you spend for more gems, gem upgrades and buildings, and at the same time, it serves as the "health bar" of your orb - a connection with major tactical consequences) ... you can also apply special effects like freezing enemies in an area of effect or adding bolts to do higher damage where the battle situation makes it necessary. 

The monsters only come in a few different shapes and sizes, but the occasional attacks of flying gem thieves who can easily destroy your main front create exciting situations anyway. As there are so many things going on, I had no time to get bored of the attackers, and even if this would have been the case: The developer offers you the option to change the speed of time flow and even pause, a player service well-appreciated.

The single levels, connected by an expanding map that offers you some freedom of strategical choice where to attack next, not only display the usual patterns of roads, building ground, pre-made buildings and so on, but also loot chests, mana pools, destructable monster nests and many other special features that help to avoid repetitivity. 

Scrolls, relics and crafting materials you loot on those battlegrounds are used to improve your character, give you new buffs and spells and thereby the power to master difficult challenges on the map in which you were defeated in your first attempt - which makes the final victory even sweeter. 

Talking about accomplishments: Apart from being an entertaining and surprisingly deep TD game, this is a real achievement factory. You get those for every single little step and discovery, and as there are many (see above), you are practically showered in them. I think I received around 80 in the first five hours of gameplay (more than Skyrim has in total!), and there are more than 400 to earn here. If you are on a hunt for Steam achievements, go and get this title!

Graphics and sound are functional, they add some nice details to the whole experience, but the dynamic gameplay is definitely the major strength of this product. Within its own genre, I judge it to be an 8.5/10.

28906185.review:
I was really torn wheter i should give this game a thumbs up or a thumbs down. To review this game you basically have to think of it as two seperate games. There is the early game where you're just trying to beat all the levels, hunt some achievements and experiment with different ideas and strategies without really knowing what you're doing.

This part is fun, well done and i'd totally recommend it.

And then there is the late-game where have to do crazy long endurance runs (i've seen people going for over 24hours) that follow a very strict strategy and it basically becomes an endless grind for XP. 

This part "could" be fun (if you're into that kind of thing) but unfortunately the game can't handle the crazy amounts of monsters and the huge numbers it has to deal with later on. It's boring enough to sit there for hours doing nothing but enraging all the waves to max and upgrading your gems. But the horrible lags make it excruciating.

So is it good or bad? 

If you're looking for a good tower defense game, that can capture your attention for a few days.. buy it. Totally worth it.
If you're a completionist that wants to push his gems and wizard levels to the max.. don't buy it. The game will break your soul trying to do that.

28841713.review:
I purchased this game without knowing anything about it. It was on a 80% off sale s
it piqued my interest and as several of my friends had it I gave it a shot. I give this
game a 10/10 for its design, polish and addictive gameplay and would dare to say its
worth even full prize.


CONTENT
I spent several hours already and even tho its always the same (protect your orb and 
kill off any critters before they can reach you) theres a ton of diversity in form of 
gems, skills, map types, special challenges, tasks etc etc. I didnt yet uncover the 
whole map or unlock every skill or tower or gem but so far I m busy whenever I find 
the time to log in. It shows that this game isnt "new" as it got additional content 
en masse over time and being faced with all of it now is kinda overwhelming but also 
very exciting as I realize I ll play this for a looooooooooong time.

THE GOAL
You ll be thrown into a maze with 1 orb at the end and 1 or multiple entries for 
critters. Sometimes the map also has Monster spawners in them including even more 
critters per wave. Each map has a pre-defined number of waves coming at you and 
also pre-determined critter strenghts. Each passing second will contribute you with 
mana, killing a critter adds yet more mana and of course there are other means to 
tap mana (environmental, gems, shrines). You use that mana in order to build stuff, 
create gems or upgrade existing gems. You can also just let it collect which enables 
you to increase your "mana level" representing your "interest" known from other games. 
Basically the more interest you can accumulate the higher the bonuses you ll get so 
the game "taunts" you with trying to beat the map with the least necessary tools 
forcing you to keep trying new combinations in order to maximize your result.

TOWERS
I call em towers but in reality these only represent the bases of your mazes (hey, 
that rhymed). Things like a tower foundation or trap foundation or booster 
foundations. All of these dont do anything on their own but require gems placed into 
them in order to damage critters.

GEMS
There is a whole list of different gems with different attributes. Some damage, others 
debuff or buff. You dont have access to all of them at all times. The map you play 
decides which gem types are available to you. Gems can be placed or upgraded as PURE 
which means their attribute is especially strong or you can combine different colors 
of gems in order to combine their attributes. This means that both attributes become 
weaker then in a pure gem but the obvious advantage is that you now use 2 attributes 
at the same time. You can combine as many as 4 different colors in a single gem. 
Using multi-colored gems will increase their upgrade cost as well. Theres a whole 
segment of theory crafting behind the combination of gems. I didnt get all of it yet 
but I realize it supports rather INSANE combos which enables you to push  your results 
into incredible heights.

SKILLS and TALISMANS
These represent a kind of progression curve for you. Skill points are mostly dependant 
on your level (each level grants you a certain number of points and also certain feats 
and tasks in the game do the same) and let you "purchase" bonuses in certain areas. 
Maybe you d like to get more mana per kill or make certain types of gems stronger? 
There are 25 skills to chose from and each one can be upgraded "unknown" times (my 
highest so far is 15 and I dont think it ends there anytime soon). In addition unspent 
skill points increase your starting mana so again you are faced with hard decisions as 
being able to create and place strong gems before the first wave appears can represent 
easy-mode. You can reset your skills and redistribute your skills at any time allowing 
you to micro-manage for specific maps.

Talismans on the other hand are fueled by shadow cores and these are aquired by 
defeating enemies in general and certain critter types. Before you can use shadow cores 
you gonna need talismans and getting them is kind of a lottery thing. Theres a whole 
list of different types at different rarities. You have a "wheel" of amulettes enabling 
you to place a finite amount of them so replacing or keeping them in stock is a good 
idea later on once you start to "optimize" your amulets for the maps you run. The ones 
I used so far only have minor bonuses (up to +9% on certain things) but I havent found 
any higher rarity ones yet. You can use your shadow cores to boost the rarity chance of 
any talismans as well.


MAPS
Maps are unique in design and each one of them has a specific list of gems it allows to
use. That doesnt mean you have access to all of them at the start as certain gem types 
need to be unlocked first before you can use them."Mazing" is a critical thing inside 
maps which you accomplish by placing walls in a pattern to force critters to take a 
longer route or come by certain spots multiple times in order to increase your possible 
kill time or make your placed gems more valuable (by being able to attack passing matters 
more then once with the same gem). Many maps also have structures or other specials 
which represent additional challenges. This could be mana wells, monster dens, shrines, 
spectres and (probably) many more (those are the only ones I had so far).

ENDGAME
I m still busy unlocking stuff so probably havent seen half of everything but I spotted 
the "Endurance mode" already which is activatable whenever you beat a map and represents 
"open mode". Probably not "open" as they have a finite number of waves but the ones I 
sampled so far ramp up so quickly in difficulty that I gonna need a lot more levels, 
skills and resources in general to get em done. I read that some of them require 
"multiple hours" to complete so looking forward to the fun. At the moment my wizard is 
to weak and cannot beat more then a couple waves in endurance mode before he gets overrun.

There are not really any "hard limits" on stuff like in other TD games where you can upgrade 
your towers a finite number of times before you reach the "max". I ve seen videos with 
incredible gem levels, wizard levels and overall numbers shown on the screen rivaling a T13
rift run in Diablo3 (sorry). None of these can be reached with simply beating a map. You 
gonna need certain wizard levels, certain skill levels, certaon talisman set-ups and 
certain gem combinations in order to unlock them. Its the carrot which pushes you even 
further. I know I ll be there eventually myself but first I need to unlock all the required 
skills, farm more shadow cores, get more skill points etc etc in order to be prepared.



You dont start a new map completely at zero. All the shadow cores, skill points, skills 
and talismans you aquire beforehand are at your disposal and stay with you in between 
maps making your wizard stronger the longer and more you play. I love this "nurturing" 
of a character of mine and seeing myself become stronger over time

Another strong point for the game is that unlike other TD games you can use multiple 
strategies to beat a map. There are certain set-ups which allow you optimal results and 
these get fine-tuned all the time by hard-core players going after the elusive high-score 
(each map saves your highest score as a taunt for you to beat) but you have a lot more leeway 
to beat maps "regulary" giving you a lot of freedom and choice.


UNKNOWN STUFF
I stumbled across things like a "compass" which I can manipulate but dont have a clue what
to do with yet. Combining stuff also is obvious at first but there are detals to it that
will be hidden to you until you start to experiment around. I havent seen half the maps yet 
but many hold extra challenges which force you to think about what you do and WHEN to do it.
The game seems to evolve constantly and doesnt remain static. It fascinates me and hours keep 
going by at an alarming rate. 

I dont regret buying this game and recommend it 100%

28724048.review:
This is one of those games I find it hard to recommend to many people. However for a Tower Defense game, GemCraft - Chasing Shadows is pretty great.

I won't be discussing the plot of the series, but I will say there are four games in the series so far. The first three being flash games: Chapter One: The Forgotten, Chapter Zero: The Gem of Eternity, Lost Chapter: Labyrinth, and finally Chapter 2: Chasing Shadows.

The gameplay is very much of what you expect of a Tower Defense game. Place some towers, set up defenses, and don't let the monsters get to your base. However it isn't bright and colorful in this world. Everything is grim, dark, and depressing. After all, the world is much of a wasteland with those monsters around.

Your main line of defense is gems. Yes, gems. These are your "defense units" of the game. There are a total of 9 colors of gems in the game, each with their unqiue own effects (note that Lime from Labyrinth is removed and White and Black are added).

Besides being able to build towers, you are able to build walls, amplifiers (which are towers that power other towers..but they need a gem equipped to be used), and traps (which focus on effects more than damage).

..I'd go on to cover the rest of the gameplay, but I'd run out of space by the time I do so. Plus there's an in-game tutorial feature that helps you learn over time about almost everything gameplay wise.

The presentation as I said before is dark and depressing. However I did not mention how..enchanting the music is. It's hard to explain, but there's just something about the soundtrack that I really enjoy. While we're talking about presentation, the game obviously looks better than the first three games due to it not being limited as a flash game this time around. Heck, I can say it runs better as well.


Overall, I do enjoy GemCraft - Chasing Shadows. Now there's one thing I lacked to mention. The game is [b]very[/b] grind heavy. You'll end up grinding and backtracking to various levels to level up, just to be able to take on new levels, or possibly just to unlock something you missed before such as a Skill Tome or Battle Trait. There is also the overabundance of achievements, 419 to be specific. Most of which are simple, but eventually it will be difficult or possibly time wasting. There is also the "Iron Wizard" mode that can be unlocked. Meaning, you guessed it, this grind heavy game just got harder. Also there's a single achievement tied to it. "Good luck."

If you're a "Completionist" or happen to be a casual player, you're better off turning back now as this is a long game. A [i]very[/i] long game. However if you're looking for something to spend your time on, and don't mind the repetitive grinding, I may as well recommend this game to ya. The full price of $9.99 isn't that bad, especially looking at how much playtime you get off of it.

28720195.review:
[h1]GemCraft, ou comment passé 1 heure a faire des gem pour one-shot des monstres[/h1]
GemCraft est un Tower defence unique dans sont genre, contrarement au autre tower defence, GemCraft permet de faire des tours avec des atributs et capaciters 100% personalisé en combinant des gems pour créer des combinaisons puisantes.
GemCraft est assez complet, il a une une durée de vie entre 50 heures et 300 heures, il est complexe tout en restant simple a prendre en mains.

28695113.review:
As someone who's played all previous games in the series, I had high hopes for Chasing Shadows. The flash version blew those expectations out of the water, and the Steam version has only improved this game. I'd consider this game to be the best tower defense game out there.

Pros:
- Custom window size
- Easy to pick up
- Tons of replayability (endurance mode)
- Lots of achievements
- Battle traits don't cost any shadow cores (compared to the flash version)
- Fun to play and always engaging
- More fields (compared to the flash version)
- Customization options to suit your playstyle

Cons:
- This game is normally 10 dollars, which might be overpriced for some (I got mine on a sale)
- Advanced mana-farms/endurance mode play can lag low-end computers
- Story isn't very strong (but you don't play tower defense games for the story)

If I had to rate it, I would give it a 9.5/10. This game is a must-have for any tower defense enthusiasts, and even if you don't play tower defense, I highly recommend you give it a try :)

28668328.review:
GemCraft habe ich vor Jahren schon auf Armorgames gespielt. Ich kenne inzwischen sehr viele Tower Defense-Spiele und GemCraft gehört für mich seit längerem zu den Top-Titeln. Schon vor Jahren hat es mich sehr gefesselt und die Steam-Portierung ist eine tolle Sache!

[h1]Ein paar Eckdaten eines tollen Games![/h1]
[list][*] Sehr einfacher Zugang mit steigender Komplexität: Features werden freigespielt
[*] Das Spiel ermöglicht kurze Sessions, aber man kann locker viele Stunden verbringen
[*] Edelsteine, Kosten etc. lassen sich über Skills verbessern. Skills müssen erspielt werden
[*] Stimmungsvolle, auch auf die Dauer nicht störende Ambientmusik
[*] Abwechslungsreiches Leveldesign, teils mit Überraschungen
[*] Nette Hintergrundgeschichte 

[*] [b]Talismansystem[/b]
[list][*] Talismane droppen im Spiel, es gibt verschiedene Güteklassen
[*] Sie bieten Boni wie bspw. mehr Schaden gegen bestimmte Gegnertypen
[*] Die Grundwerte und Anzahl der Boni hängen von der Güteklasse ab
[*] Maximal 15 Talismane kann man nutzen
[*] Talismane sind einige Male aufwertbar
[/list] 


[*] [b]Hohe Wiederspielbarkeit[/b]
[List][*] Über 400 Achievements (jetzt auch auf Steam ^^)
[*] Massenhaft Einstellungsmöglichkeiten für die Level
[*] Das Skillsystem lädt ständig zum XP-Farmen ein (immer besser werden)
[*] Tonnenweise Statistiken und Highscores für jedes einzelne Level
[*] Für Suche nach immer besseren Talismanen geht man gerne immer größere Herausforderungen ein
[/list]
[/list]

[h1]Tipps für den späteren Spielverlauf[/h1]
Im fortgeschrittenen Spielverlauf kann es sein, dass einige Level deutliche Herausforderungen darstellen. Hier empfehle ich euch, die Tiefe des Spieles auszunutzen. Nutzt die Optionen des Skillsystems (ab und an mal neu verteilen) und probiert verschiedene Strategien aus (bspw. mal mehr Fallen nutzen oder sich auf bestimmte Wirkungen wie Gift oder Mana-Leech fokussieren). Die Level im Endlosmodus zu spielen ist eine gute Möglichkeit, XP zu farmen, um so an mehr Skillpunkte zu gelangen.

Ich wünsche euch viel Spaß, GemCraft ist ein wirklich großartiges Indi-Game!

GemCraft - Chasing Shadows gehört zu meinen liebsten Spielen. Nachdem ich auf Amorgames die Vorgänger komplett durchgespielt und sehnsüchtig auf eine Fortsetzung gewartet hatte, freute ich mich umso mehr als ich GemCraft in Steam sah.

28119145.review:
I haven't played a Tower Defense game in years. I got h this one on sale, let it sit for a bit, and then decided to check it out. And... I am glad I did. Yeah, I know. I don't have a ton of time in. Yet. That will change, 

Pros:
[list][*]Singleplayer. No a-holes coming in and destroying your defenses just for sheets and giggles. It's all on you, you vs. the AI. I like that. Idiot griefers in MP TD games in the past are why I stopped playing. Not having to deal with them here is a HUGE plus. [*]Not "easy". It is easy to pick up, but  can already tell in my short playtime, that it will not be easy to master. You need good strategy and planning, even early on. [*]Interersting story to the game. Reading the pages as you unlock them adds a nice element. [*] Nice graphics and audio. Nothing spectacular, but nothing ugly either. It's bright enough and colorful enough to captivate, without being blinding with flashes and flying particles everywhere. The ambient sounds are realistic and not overwhemingly loud or distracting. [/list]

Cons:
[list][*]Needs a little more of a Tutorial for new players, and those who are not familiar with Tower Defense games. But this is a minor thing, there is a Tutorial Booklet with all of the neccessary commands, it just does not explain to a first-timer how things work, and how they work together or against each other. Game is forgiving though- you can go back and replay any field until you get the hang of it. [*]May be a bit overpriced at full price ($10 USD), for what you are getting. [*]Steam Achievements- if you are hoping for a quick and easy 100% game, this isn't the game for you, lol! There are 400+ Achievements, and the global stats show that many of them take a ton of time and effort to get.  (But if you like challenging Achievements- this [b]IS[/b] a game for you!) [/list]

Overall? 8/10. Not a "must have", but a solid "Should have", especially if you love Tower Defense and can get it on sale.

Now, I need to go and play this game some more. It calls to me...

27593631.review:
I've been playing the freeware games in this series for years so I'm glad to pay for a game that stays true to its predecessors.  The same GemCraft tower defense combat gameplay is present with many welcome refinements.  

Beyond the tower defense game, the player is given quite a number of ways to upgrade their power with a lot of options to choose from, though options need to be earned.

The game will always present a challenge for you to overcome with the ability to give yourself larger challenges along the way.  Each scenario also allows for an endless mode after the objective level is reached, though it seems as though the game wants you to power up significantly before you get serious about trying them.

If you like 'tough but fair' tower defense this is a pretty good buy.

27570136.review:
I am tempted to call this the ultimate TD game. It's a TD game that everyone looking for a new TD game should pick up and try. It has numerous levels. It has interesting upgrades. It has a good amount of grind that is made interesting by a variety of valid strategies. It has interesting and unique concepts.

 But there is one thing that really sets it apart from other TD games: there is a highly mathematical late game that has spawned a community of math heads searching for the perfect gem. At a certain point the game isn't any longer about beating the levels. Instead it is about coming as far as possible in an endurance run, using the most cost efficient gems and deploying your strategy in a way that minimizes lag while stile allowing you to farm the enemies with mana gems (=gaining currency). Suddenly everything happens in orders of magnitude.

The lag is the only downside really. It is a flash game originally, and at some point you start sending continuous waves of enemies with increased speed. This kills the fps. So playing an late-game endurance run is kind of a nerd thing. It can easily take 5-10 hours and it requires maintenance.

But it's a great TD even without these endurance runs.

26832393.review: GemCraft est un condensé des meilleurs mécaniques de Tower Defense classique, il sera compliqué de développer chaque fonctionnalité, mais dans les autres atouts du jeu on retrouve, en vrac, de nombreuses priorités de ciblage, la possibilité d'adapter la portée des tours pour toujours plus de stratégie, des statistiques dans tous les sens, des options dans tous les sens, pas de véritable farm possible, puisqu'il faut faire plus d'expérience que l'essai précédent sur une carte afin d'en gagner à nouveau, la stratégie de balance que donnent les points de skill non dépensés qui offrent plus de mana de départ, les sorts qui donnent des bonus d'expérience si beaucoup sont touchés, mais qui dit beaucoup d'ennemis, dit danger, voilà quelques aperçus des nombreuses mécanique du jeu. Mais là où GemCraft : Chasing Shadow brille bien plus que tout autre Tower Defense, c'est dans sa précision et sa manipulation des nombres. En effet, ici toutes les variables du jeu sont claires et accessibles, on ne se contente pas d'un vague "Plus efficace contre les géants", d'un "Difficulté plus élevé" ou d'un absurde "Améliore la portée", non, là vous avez des chiffres et des nombres à ne plus savoir quoi en faire, la moindre statistique améliorable et/ou qui altère un quelconque aspect dans le jeu est indiquée de manière précise, avec des chiffres précis, si bien qu'on sait exactement à quoi s'attendre lorsque l'on améliore tel ou tel talent. À un point où il n'y a pas de regrets lorsque l'on agit, puisque l’on n’agit pas dans le hasard ou l'inconnu. D'autant plus que, comme la plupart des mécaniques du jeu, rien n'est gravé dans le marbre, on peut réinitialiser sans malus la plupart des éléments du jeu pour se re-spécialiser facilement, par exemple.

26488344.review:
tl;dr : Super fun TD with a simplistic approach but a lot of depth.

Extremely fun and addictive TD game with a simplistic (but super efficient) approach. You can always be challenged more. And you can always progress.

Just 3 monster types but many modifiers. And enraging. And occasional special monsters (flying ones). And beacons to take care of. And things to destroy. And special objectives to unlock skills and traits.

Just 9 gem types but all the combinations are possible. And they do different things in towers, traps and amplifiers. And you can also use them as bombs. Or to enrage waves for more challenge.

The game is simplistic but never boring thanks to a lot of variation in what happens, what you need to do (apart from building towers), and what you can do.

Dozens of levels, very cool "spell crafting" mechanic, very customizable and rewarding difficulty system, hundreds of achievements (which give a bonus so you're motivated to get them). All the systems (looting, crafting, talisman, skills, environments, achievements, traits, gem bombs, enraging, towers/traps/amplifiers, flying ones, beacons...) everything is well designed and smart. And the game is still interesting even after you played hundreds of times because it's never the same thing twice, and by increasing the difficulty you are always challenged.

I'm almost 400 hours into the game and I'm not done. I haven't even finished every map on every difficulty setting. And I even have a few achievements left to unlock.

What other game can keep you entertained for hundreds of hours for that price ?
