20669106.review:
[h1]======================================[/h1]
[h1][b]GemCraft - Chasing Shadows[/b][/h1] (Read on for the full review!)
[h1]======================================[/h1]
[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
Gemcraft is an astonishingly well crafted tower defense game with great difficulty scaling, sufficient graphics and audio, and lots of content. The RPG mechanics and lore give it life and purpose. Highly recommended.
[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]Pros:[/b][/h1]
+ Graphics: I like the variety between bleak and vivid colors.
+ Audio: Not amazing, but the hit & death sounds are quite satisfying.
+ Concept: Gem-enhanced towers? Gem bombs? Gem traps? Gem amplifiers? Yes.
+ Difficulty: Slightly easy after a spike. You can then increase the difficulty for more reward.
+ Replayability: I enjoy replaying levels with extra challenge to see what I can pull off.
+ RPG Mechanics: Unlockables, upgrades, levels, skills & spells, and story.
+ Lore: Well written, simple, given in scraps, great for those that do or don't want it.
+ UI: Simply put, the UI is extremely well done. Simple, appealing, aesthetically pleasing.
+ Variety: There's a gem for every playstyle, and many levels offering various gems.

[h1][b]Cons:[/b][/h1]
- Brevity: Eventually, going through all the basic levels to get to unlocks can get monotonous. I would prefer fewer levels, offering more tight design and unique challenges.
- Rewards: I'm nitpicking here, but I dislike how getting really far in endurance offers much less experience than getting through the normal map on a higher difficulty or with trials on.

[h1][b]Neutral:[/b][/h1]
+/- Graphics and audio are well designed, but could be better looking/sounding.

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]Introduction:[/b][/h1]
Welcome to Gemcraft - Chasing Shadows, the tower defense game where you use various gems and combinations thereof to make your towers methodically destroy your opposition. Gemcraft brings so much to the table with its lore, mechanics, and fitting design aesthetics. There are many options to suit your playstyle, and a lovely coming together of genres to make your experience fresh and exciting. Let's take a deeper look:

[h1][b]Gameplay:[/b][/h1]
You have 9 gems at your disposal: Red, yellow, orange, green, blue, cyan, purple, white, black; or chain hit, critical hit, mana leeching, poison, slowing, suppressing, armor tearing, poolbound, and bloodbound respectively. You are given select gems to beat every field with. You can use bombs, traps, towers, and amplifiers. A gem-enhanced entity that has a single or 'pure' gem will always be the strongest form of that gem. If you are to fuse gems, the individual components will be weaker, but the overall effect could be much stronger; an easy example of this would be combining almost any of them with the red gem, chain hit. I also should point out that you can fuse two pure gems of the same level to get them to the next level. (This works with hybrids, as well.) Some gems work better as traps than towers, green (or poison) being a good example of this, however, you are generally free to make things work however you wish, utilizing many or few of the tools at your disposal. On a final note on gems and their killing mechanics, I should mention that amplifiers don't seem to benefit from having their gems upgraded, they simply need any ol' gem present to provide a flat bonus.

Moving away from gems, you have 25 skills that can be unlocked. Examples include cheaper construction, more effective gem bombs, and spell enhancement. Some of these are crucial, while others come down to preference. You can reset them at any time. You also have six spells. Examples are an AOE freeze and a special beam or barrage for your towers. There are two ways of unlocking skills and spells, tomes and wizard towers. Tomes require you to kill certain enemies such as 50 giants that have been frozen in their presence. Wizard towers require you to break locks, usually by hitting them directly in different ways. You recieve talismans from beating maps, rarity based on difficulty, which do things like increase damage or experience and make gems heavier. You have a limited amount of slots for talismans. You can upgrade talismans with shadow cores or scrap them to get more. Most shadow cores will come from killing spectres. Later on, you can spend shadow cores to increase the rarity of drops.

Initially the game's difficulty will spike but once you get the mechanics down it becomes much easier. Then you have 9 trials and 3 difficulty modes to utilize. Trials are modifiers that impact the gameplay, but greatly boost your rewards. An early one adds waves and makes them arrive earlier. I recommend using this when you become familiar with a level so you can get a lot of experience. Be careful, however, because there is a mechanic where XP rewarded = current exp - previous highest exp.

You can use these mechanics to unlock field tokens, which add levels and hexes to the map. Clearing a level could unlock one or more field tokens, (and perhaps a scrap of lore) allowing you the option to prioritize certain paths through the game's fields which enables you to get to unlocks faster, or put off a tough stage. The flexibility and depth presented in Gemcraft makes for a very compelling experience not found even in most AAA TD games.

[h1][b]Graphics:[/b][/h1]
The graphics in Gemcraft are serviceable. They are great on some points, but mainly the UI. The UI has everything just the right size. It is thematic but not overly fancy or convoluted. Things are properly highlighted or out of the way. Some aspects may be large and visual as opposed to other aspects being smaller and text-based, tucked away for those that desire more information. Everything is very well laid out, easy to get to, and navigation is quick and simple. With the amount of options present, this is a great boon for Gemcraft. The map is quite beautiful, the field level icons and gem graphics are nice, and the enemies look alright. I wish the enemies had a bit more variety though, being mostly variations of bugs. The textures could also use improvement in resolution, and perhaps some in their design. Many of the stages end up looking bland because of said design flaws of the textures.

[h1][b]Audio:[/b][/h1]
The music is good, not too obtrusive. The hit and death sounds are satisfying. Everything that needs a sound, has one, and usually they are nice. Like the graphics, however, I can't help but feel like there is a certain level of polish missing, that slight flair that can take something from amateur to professional. Noting, however, that Gemcraft - Chasing Shadows is also a free browser based tower defense game, this is all actually quite impressive.

[h1][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h1]
So, in conclusion, Gemcraft - Chasing Shadows is an excellent tower defense game with fun, depth, and style in spades. The concept is  beautiful. There are numerous options available, offering satisfying levels of control, and the excellent UI makes it exceptionally easy to play and navigate. The game can be as casual or hardcore as you'd like, and would be great for kids, adults, newbies and veterans alike. I recommend Gemcraft at full price. On sale is fine, too. On a deep sale, is also fine, however, you should definitely purchase this title, one way or the other. The dev deserves support, and the game is easily worth the money even at double the full price.

20592796.review:
Обиженная женщина может быть опасна, особенно если она – архидемонесса. Некогда волшебники, движимые отнюдь не высокими целями, призвали ее в свой мир. Но не вышло из этой затеи ничего хорошего. Королева теней, как ее назвали, стала настоящим проклятьем. Она способна порождать ужасные тени, призраков, насылать демонов (тени – это как ее кровь). Уничтожить ее невозможно, по крайней мере никто не знает как. Единственное, что удается волшебникам, оставшимся отдуваться за своих алчных коллег-призывателей, - временно запечатать злодейку с помощью Камня Вечности (Gem of Eternity). Однако через несколько десятилетий она неизбежно вырывается на свободу аккурат к тому моменту, когда о ней все забывают. Поэтому ее и называют еще Забвенная (Forgotten). К счастью, она довольно предсказуема. Каждый раз, когда вырывается, идет в одну сторону, по одной дороге, а именно в Кузницу Духов (Spiritforge). Что ей там надо, неизвестно: видимо, никто не спрашивал. Или спрашивающие не оставались в живых. Как бы то ни было, нельзя дать ей добраться до Кузницы. Мало ли что произойдет, вдруг вся вселенная взорвется…
Вы - волшебник. Причем, незаурядный, и, наверное, самый хитрый. Волшебник, который предугадав свое поражение, заранее поставил ловушку на эту архидемонессу:  установил на дороге магические врата с косами. Забвенная вселилась в его тело аки чужой в жертву, пошла по дороге и в результате получила волшебной косой по лбу.  Она вылетела из тела волшебника, он снова стал собой. И оказался практически единственным, кто теперь может остановить Забвенную с помощью магии самоцветов. 
Гемкрафт - это намного больше, чем «защита башни». В этой игре у вас целый ряд задач:
1.	Придумывать стратегию, как построить башни, стены, ловушки и т.д., чтобы не дать монстрам королевы теней добраться до орба (orb), артефакта, который вы защищаете.
2.	Самоцветы могло апгрейдить, комбинировать, у них масса разных свойств. Название игры как бы намекает, что крафтинг гемов (т.е. самоцветов) здесь обширная тема.
3.	Добывать ману. Мана – это как бы и валюта, и показатель жизненных сил в игре.  Многие игроки изощряются в создании конструкций из ловушек и вспомогательных камней, которые называют «фермы маны» или «манофермы» (mana farms). С их помощью можно сильно повысить свой прогресс, и их создание – это целое искусство. 
4.	Раскрывать секреты игры. В Гемкрафте встречаются секретные моды, тайные уровни и т.д. 
5.	Зарабатывать достижения. Разработчики не поскупились. Достижений около… 400.
Однако, на мой взгляд, в игре есть 2 серьезных минуса. Это, во-первых, мрачная атмосфера. Суровые, негостеприимные ландшафты оправдывают свое название «Дикие земли» или «Глухомань» (Wilderness). Погода не балует – очень часто идет сильный дождь, который нисколько не мешает нашествию монстров. На фоне темных и мрачных красок самоцветы смотрятся более ярко, но общая картина безысходности не навевает положительных эмоций. Во-вторых, игра на английском языке. Русификатора на данный момент нет. Только вирусы в интернете, замаскированные под русификатор. А для успешного игрового процесса нужно глубокое понимание характеристик этих камней, талисманов, скиллов и т.д. Просто так строить побольше башен, бессистемно набивать их самоцветами – не очень эффективная тактика. Все равно что заклинанием «Удар огня» в Morrowind попробовать зажигать спичку или биотическим умением «Бросок» в Mass Effect поковырять в носу.  Страшная картина. 
В общем, эту игру стоит приобретать, если вы фанат этой серии игр, хорошо владеете английским, если вы наслаждаетесь процессом игры больше, чем результатом, обожаете долго обдумывать стратегии, опробовать все возможности, и ничего другого так не любите как заниматься крафтингом игровых предметов. Тогда эта игра точно придется вам по вкусу. В остальных случаях, мне думается, лучше отдать предпочтение другим играм жанра «защита башни», более простым и понятным. 
Возможно, эта игра застала меня не в подходящем настроении. Может быть, спустя какое-то время я снова стану в нее играть, и она покажется мне очень интересной и захватывающей. Но сейчас совершенно противоположные ощущения.

GemCraft is an interesting beast, and if you like tower defense, then this game is for you. That is unless you like having your hand held through the process. This is a game that commands your understanding before you can succeed, and unless you're planning out your skills and utilising your talismans, it can quickly get the best of you. 
As far as I have seen, this game offers a wealth of replayability, with the ability to go back to any map you've completed and play it with difficulty-increasing modifiers, and also just harder difficulty levels, not to mention an "Endurance" mode. Ultimately you could spend a tons of hours just work through the levels, and it's a greatly soothing game to play when you just want to chill.

20514698.review:
It may not look like much on the surface, but this game is a diamond in the rough...GET IT?!?!! HAR HAR
*ahem* Anyway, this is a ridiculously good tower defense. I thought Defense Grid was good, but this pretty much blows it away. I can't really put my finger on any one thing that makes it so good; it's just fun. There are a lot of decisions to be made not just in your defense build, but also in between missions with skills, talisman slots, traits, etc. Plenty of content and depth here. I also really like that you can seamlessly transition from any mission into the endless mode. If you're having fun with your build on a particular map or the layout of the map itself, you can continue playing on it in endless and just see how much XP you can rack up. About the only thing I would wish for is that the different gem types had more distinctive visual effects, instead of just different colors of the little bolts, but that's a pretty minor gripe. Bottom line, if you enjoy tower defense, you really can't beat this game, especially for the price.

Truly amazed by this game and once I make it through the base game I will try out the other fun stuff it offers.  I love the fact you can place things where you actually want to put them and aren't restricted to set places like some other TD games do.  I will keep my eyes open for future installments of this game. 20481148.review:
If you're new to Gem Craft, google it, and play browser based. After a few levels you'll see why it is so well loved, (if you're one to like TD games) and you'll likely think to yourself: "Man, wouldn't this be great fullscreen?"

Yes, of course it's better, and more content overal too! Though, It should be noted that holding the shift key, while building and moving gems, will slow your game no mater the circumstance (no enemys/good hardware). To remedy this: simply pause the game as it is a single player experence; there is no need to rush. I have encountered few problems otherwise. The game is finished with the expected, but well executed pixelish graphical style of its type. This TD will give you a great varriety of strategic choice both durring the levels, and throughout the meta-game/overworld. It is the one game in the sea of thousands that I would comfortably recomend buying off-sale. It is truely worth the ~$10, and would give the creative genius behind the series what they deserve for such a well thought-through, risk/reward strategy title. It really does feel like the game has been fully fleshed out. It is far from what a browser flash game is normally.

Now, I know I haven't told you many specifics about Gem Craft, but this is because you can easily experience the mechanics with the browser version yourself. And if you are too lazy for that, there are many, many more reviews that actually break the game down properly for what it is.



This is my first review, and will likely be my only one for a while. I don't write negative reviews. I don't write positive reviews. I only wrote this after seeing the recent sale, and I was reminded of the near perfection this gem has been polished to.

-Thanks Game in a Bottle!

20456754.review:
Was die Mechanik von GemCraft - Chasing Shadows betrifft, 
bin ich der selben Meinung wie so viele Andere hier.
Definitiv das komplexeste TD Spiel, welches mir bis zum heutigen Tage an unter die Augen gekommen ist. 

Der Skill Tree hat eine recht weit gefächerte Auswahl mit der man seinen Spielstil ziemlich individuell gestalten kann. Die Bestückung des Talisman, der quasi als Träger verschiedener Perks fungiert, bietet nochmals immense Individualisierungsmöglichkeiten wie man an die einzelnen Level heran zu gehen wünscht. 

Die zusätzliche Möglichkeit verschiedene Gems miteinander fusionieren zu lassen, ergibt unzählige Tower Varianten, die im Vergleich zu anderen TD Spielen auch noch beinahe beliebig viele Upgrades zulässt - die Sandbox der TD Spiele sozusagen. Die Karten sind allesamt verschieden gehalten und zwingen durch ihren unterschiedlichen Aufbau der Pfade und möglichen Tower Positionen zu immer wieder neuen Taktiken. Die Balance ist dabei erhaben und wodurch kein einzelner Tower bevorteilt wird. Hier spielen viele Jahre an Feintuning ins Gesamtwerk des Spiels. Wer sich informieren möchte, sollte im Internet zur Vergangenheit von GemCraft etwas googlen und wird verstehen warum die oberen Zeilen diesem Spiel gerecht werden. Dennoch wie immer: Alles Geschmackssache, doch von meinen an die zwanzig TD Spielen, sticht dieses kleine Jewel dermaßen raus, dass ich um diese Bewertung als Dankeschön an die Entwickler nicht herum kam.

When I saw GemCraft - Chasing Shadows on steam I had to have it! On the moment of writing I finished the story line and got 38 hours on record. I will probably get 200+ hours in the coming months.

In my opinion when it comes to Tower Defense, this is THE game franchise you must get.
Pros/features:
- very deep gameplay
- good storyline

- allows for additional upgrades of tower without upgrading the tower itself (amplifiers)

- 3 difficulty modes 
- difficulty traits with different adjustable levels
- static upgrades/improvements via talisman fragments which can be collected by playing levels
- wide variety of enemies and wave types (25+ combinations)
- six different spells to use during a level
- 4 speed modes which can be changed during gameplay including pause


cons:

20411424.review:
This has to be the... best tower defence game I've played.. ever.

The amount of options you have when it comes to upgrading skills, the way you can combine gems(gems are you towers, for anyone who hadn't figured that out), the talisman system and the way of how you unlock levels is awesome.
And hey, achievement collectors, get ready to collect 419 achievements.

In my personal opinion this game is completely fleshed out, the gameplay experience is great, no flaws, as far as I am concerned, after 15 hours of gameplay.

[h1]Risk, reward.[/h1]
This games risk-reward system is amazing, you can bomb levels that are about to come with gems to enrage the level, increasing the HP, amount of monsters and amount of armour they have, but you gain mana(Mana is your 'money' in this game)+XP for it, do you want to bomb 2 levels for some mana+xp and risk loosing or do you want to keep it safe? You can even build strategies on some levels around this.
The game also has traits, traits are some things you can bump up for each level, for example you can make all the monsters have more armour(scales from 1 to 7), you can make it so you only receive your mana earned every 10 seconds while playing, making levels come faster, up to 50% faster, in return for a large XP bonus multiplier, the game also has 3 different difficulties(difficulties are tied to each level, the entire game is not hard if you set it to hard, you set each levels difficulty).
This game handles the risk-reward system very good, it's absolutely brilliant, I was very impressed by that.

The actual gameplay is well paced(yes, the game has fast forward options), it keeps you entertained and it's very fun and oh man, it is very addicting.

The game has a story but it's not really that entertaining, every now and then you unlock 1 or more pages of lore/story/whatever you want to call it, each page is about 30 words long, in my experience all they do is add to the dark and grim atmosphere of the game, I'm not invested in an actual story like I am when I'm playing Walking Dead(an extreme example but you get the point).


9/10, amazing game, an absolute must buy if you're into tower defence games, I strongly recommend it if you want to dip your feet in a tower defence game for the first time as well.

20399485.review:
One of the top Tower Defense games available today. 
It easily sits alongside Defense Grid and Prime World: Defenders as one of my favourite examples of the genre. 
Initially it may seem too easy and feature out-dated graphics, but to ignore it because of this would be a HUGE mistake. This is probably the deepest / most complex Tower Defense game available and has 100s of hours of play available should you want to explore its modes fully.
With a HUGE variety of towers, skills, maps and a couple of fascinating and rewarding additional gameplay mehcanics this provides you with almost endless variety.
The particular benefit this game offers is the ability to upgrade. You upgrade your skills, the towers available, the gameplay modifiers you can use (which each have numerous levels), your talisman (which features 100s of "perk" combinations on more than 20 fragments which randomly drop during games, all of which can be, themselves, upgraded, and have a significant impact on gameplay). Additionally there are well over 100 levels which can be played at 3 difficulties and indeed a whole alternate game mode which significantly alters the challenge / experience.
This game represents rare quality and value for money. Suffice to say I eagerly await a sequel!

Che magnifico gioco !

Con [b]Gemcraft - Chasing Shadows[/b] non ci vuole molto a capire che si è di fronte al piccolo/grande capolavoro, quello che capita una volta ogni 4-5 anni. Tower-defense profondamente tattico, intelligente e longevo. Bellissimo sia per quanto riguarda le raffinate meccaniche di gioco, sia per la curatissima e mai stancante evoluzione del personaggio, legata allo sblocco di abilità passive, attive, incantesimi e molto altro. Ogni mappa ha 3 livelli di difficoltà, una modalità endurance e modificatori sbloccabili che aggiungono penalità in cambio di boost ai punti esperienza. 
La cosa che più mi ha colpito è però la dinamicità delle mappe: ci sono tante azioni in più rispetto al semplice piazzare una torre. Non solo perchè abbiamo un vero e proprio crafting delle gemme, ma anche perchè le mappe possono offrire "eventi" casuali, edifici da distruggere e altro. 

Chiunque, anche solo leggermente interessato ai giochi tower-defense, deve prendere in considerazione questo titolo. Ma attenzione: la sua profondità richiede anche impegno, non è certo un gioco casual.
Prezioso.

20331572.review:
Don't mind my hours spent on the Steam version, because I have way more than 100+ hours on the free, web browser version itself - but now! - there's an almighty question many most probably have asked.

[h1] "Why should I buy this game when I can play it for free?" [/h1]

Well, not only that you're supporting the developers but also introducing a literal gem into your game library. In comparison with the web free version, you'll get more content on the Steam version. Since the very first GemCraft, I was amazed of how a tower defense game could be so wonderful. I've played a lot, then have focused on playing 'Chasing Shadows', which comes after 'Labyrinth'.

[h1] First Sight (TL;DR) [/h1]

You might think that it's some simple, boring, sketchy tower defense games like those on Armor Games, Kongregate and so forth. Not so! This is a tower defense game made properly, with love and basically revolutionizes the genre itself!

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

You're presented with a field composed out of roads which lead the monsters to your orb. What [i]exactly[/i] is the orb? The orb is the point you have to defend from the monsters that swarm all over, that rush towards your orb to vanquish it. If a monster touches the orb, don't fret! Yet, if you let way too many monsters at it, it will get crippled. Once your mana pool is depleted and one last monster touches the orb, it's game over. The mana acts like a shield, protecting the orb from destruction. Dropping a gem bomb (Done by pressing B (default assigned key) and dragging a gem over a spot) on the orb will decrease the banishment cost and will furthermore decrease the damage received by the monsters. 
Mana is your single resource in the whole game, used in conjuring gems, towers, traps, amplifiers, combining gems as well as in gem bombs. How is mana acquired? It is acquired by slaying monsters and mining from mana shards with a tower which has a gem equipped.
Defense of the orb is done by creating gems of a respective trait (colour) and grade. The gems can be combined altogether, the traits being distributed by half if the gem has two traits (colours), you can figure the rest out. These gems can be socketed in towers traps and amplifiers or thrown as bombs. In most fields, you will encounter shrines which can be activated by dropping a gem on them. Depending on the grade of the gem dropped on it the damage will be increased, the shrine will inflict the properties on the monsters. Walls can be used to create new paths for the monsters to follow. Traps are built on the road to inflict damage especially on the swarmlings which are quite fast, while amplifiers are built next to towers to amplify damage and properties of the gem it is amplifying. The gems can also be assigned on what to target, a building or a monster. Slowly you'll gain three area-of-effect spells and three gem enchantments, with a specific cooldown. Throughout the game you'll get talisman fragments to randomly drop which you can socket into their respective slot in the panel displayed in the 'Talisman' tab.
The level of difficulty can be easily customized, by adding traits at the beginning of the level, dropping gems on the wave tablets to enrage the monsters which will yield more mana and you can also call waves in earlier which will give you mana as well.
This game also has an experience system which rewards the player with skill points at every level gained and also with every achievement, said skill points can be spent on wizard traits that enhance your playthrough. The skill points can be stashed for a starting mana pool bonus.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

Not much can be said about the graphics but that everything is detailed quite nicely, the effects being absolutely wonderful and the way the vivid colours combine when mixing a gem with another of a different colour is overly pleasing. 

[h1] OST & SFX [/h1]

The soundtrack gives an eerie feeling when playing, driving you to think of how deeply horrifying the story is, fitting [i] exactly [/i] to the theme.

[h1] Pros 'n' Cons [/h1]

[b] Pros [/b]

+More than 150 fields to battle on
+Eerie, atmospheric music
+Variety of gems each with its own trait
+Different modes to play
+Personalization of the challenge
+Rewarding XP system
+Lots of achievements
+Infinite replayability
+Addicting

[b] Cons [/b]

-Might witness lag on certain occasions

[h1] Should you buy it? [/h1]
Totally! Highly recommended!

20316088.review:
This game is many times better than I was expecting. There are tons of levels, most with alterable paths. There are several difficulty levels, and - in addition to the preset difficulty levels - at the start of each map there are additional traits you can add to the map to make it more difficult while increasing the rewards gained.

There are tons of tower combinations that can be done on the fly, not forced to be chosen before you have seen the map they will be used on. There are 9 gems which can each be merged with each other in endless combinations. You can set those into powers, floor traps, and amplification towers. There are more skills, stats, upgrades, unlockables, and achievements than you will know what to do with at the start.

There are very few penalites for changing you towers around. You can drag and drop finished gems to different towers and they just need a couple of seconds to load into the tower. If you find you've made a gem you no longer need, it can be returned to your mana pool to get back 70% of its total crafting cost. There are hot keys to duplicate a complicated gem (hit D) for its crafting cost, or to upgrade one with a copy of itself (press U). You can drop gems as Bombs (with B) to destroy enemies on screen that passed your towers, or you can boost imcoming waves strength by dropping bombs on their text before they arrive.

If you like top-down tower-defense games, I think you will enjoy this. The closest I have played would be Defense Grid, though GemCraft isn't as story focused, there is much more content.

20315985.review:
Não gosto de fazer análises, porém as vezes abro exceção , tenho ao menos que dizer que esse jogo vale a pena.
GemCraft - Chasing Shadows é  a evolução do "GemCraft" original,  que é um jogo de navegador gratuito estilo Tower Defense  de quase 10 anos de existência. Neste game, assim como no original, o jogador tem que combinar diversos tipos de  gemas, cada uma com cores , níveis e  poderes específicos, para conter hordas e mais hordas de inimigos.  No game mais recente, porém, existem quase 200 fases e muitos desafios opcionais. Tower Defense é um dos gêneros que menos curto, porém esse game junto com Kingdon Rush me agradou bastante. Ambos os games foram criados como flash games gratuitos, possuem  quase 10 anos de existência e conheci eles no mesmo site: Kongregate. Há 10 anos atrás os jogos não costumavam ter opções de pagar para obter certo benefício ou essas micro transações nojentas de hoje em dia, de modo que mesmo você jogando a versão original gratuida  de GemCraft e Kindgon Rush, você terá a experiência de jogar um game completo. Recomendo que procure esses dois jogos em sites de games em flash para ter uma ideia do que te espera e também para comparar o efeito benéfico que a tecnologia moderna trouxe para esses dois games citados, especialmente para o GemCraft. Eu peguei o game em um bundle que se não me engano custou pouco mais de 2 dólares. Mesmo com o dólar a 4 reais, valeu muito a pena. Melhor que muito jogo de 100 reais e roda em qualquer computador.

Definitely one of the most expansive tower defense games currently available, but not necessarily the most fun.

I used to play Gemcraft on websites many many years ago, and I was surprised to see how much it has expanded and how much has been added, but it's still the old experience that I loved. The only thing that is really lacking is the variety in animations and gems still being indistinguishable from each other, which is something I love about TD games.

The amount of content is incredible, hundreds of achievements and levels make you keep to want playing.
It even offers a 'prestige' mode where you can reset all your achievements for a one-off bonus of 120 skill points, which means there's always something to work towards.

If you're a fan of either Gemcraft or even TD games in general, this is definitely worth a pickup.

If you're a tower defense junkie, out looking for "an addictive experience" to waste your life away with, then this is the heroin you need.
You can buy this game, when it's on sale, or you can play it FOR FREE in your browser (with probably some very minor limitations).
...and if you feel the need to play more than FIVE of these levels, you ARE a junkie. ...because this game is 2% experience, and 98% "chasing shadows", i.e. grinding to get more XP so that you can grind some more.
In terms of a grind fest, this is superb, though. This guy has spent many, many years perfecting the art of the tower defense grind, until he got to a point where he could SELL his tower defense game.
...but it's a freaking TOWER DEFENSE GAME!
There are TONS of these things littering the internet.
Just say no. Walk away. Do something with your life. Go outside.
...because if you don't, then this game features maybe 50-100 levels, that you have to play and RE-play about nine times each. Ask yourself: Do you want to spend several months playing a tower defense game? ...or would you rather look up the final level and the ending on YouTube? Think about it.


Update:
In case you want to know how long it takes to grind through this game, I can give you an estimate. A good game takes around 40 hours to beat. After 40 hours, you tend to get bored with a game, and it becomes a chore that you dread instead of enjoy.
Getting HALF WAY through Gemcraft, takes 65 hours. 65 hours of just grinding. You're stupid if you buy this game.

I've tried to listen to podcasts while grinding through this game, but after 87 hours, I just feel too nauseous to play anymore. I'm physically DISGUSTED by this game.

101 hours - the end nowhere in sight. Oh god, oh god, please make it stop!

20273200.review:
[h1]Flashgame GemCraft nun also auch außerhalb des Browsers.[/h1]
[u]Gameplay:[/u]
GemCraft ist ein Towerdefence-Spiel mit allen klassischen Elementen: Türme, Mauern, Damage-Spells, verschiedene Gegenertypen mit speziellen Eigenschaften in Wellen. Mehr muss dazu auch nicht gesagt werden. Chasing Shadows ist der aktuellste Teil einer Serie, die eigentlich als Flashgame auf einschlägigen Browsergame-Seiten veröffentlich wurde.
Anders als bei anderen TD-Spielen sind aber noch viele weitere Spielmechaniken verfügbar, zum Beispiel die vielfältigen Möglichkeiten Türme zu gestalten, miteinander zu kombinieren und so perfekt ausgeklügelte Systeme aus Türmen, Fallen und Verstärkern aufzubauen. Freaks finden hier eine Spielwiese zum Austoben und ausprobieren, Freizeitzocker können einfach Level für Level spielen und sich am machbaren Schwierigkeitsgrad erfreuen.
GemCraft enthält viele Rollenspiel-Elemente. Dies wird nicht nur durch Setting und Story (beides steht obwohl liebevoll gestaltet eher im Hintergrund) deutlich, sondern vor allem durch ein XP- und Item-System. Hiermit lassen sich zwischen den einzelnen Leveln die Eigenschaften der Türme, Fallen und Zaubersprüche verbessern. 
[u]Grafik:[/u]
Die Grafik ist in einfachem 2D gehalten. Von der Pixel-Optik der ersten Teile ist nur noch ansatzweise etwas zu erkennen, die visuellen Effekte wie Explosionen, Partikeleffekte und Wetter hübschen die eher düstere Optik ordentlich auf. Die Hauptlast liegt auf dem Prozessor.
[u]Steuerung:[/u]
Das Spiel wird eigentlich mit der Maus gesteuert, ist aber mit einer Vielzahl von Hotkeys ausgestattet, deren Verwendung ich ausdrücklich empfehle. Die Hotkeys sind dabei oft so belegt, dass sie den Anfangsbuchstaben der Funktionen entsprechen und nicht einer anatomisch angenehmen Anordnung auf der Tastatur. Umbelegen lassen sich die Hotkeys leider nicht.
[u]Langzeitmotivation:[/u]
Im Vergleich zu anderen Spielen ist die Langzeitmotivation relativ hoch. Das eigentliche Spiel bietet bereits eine ansehnliche Spielzeit von je nach Spielweise bestimmt 20 Stunden. Auf dem direkten Weg zum finalen Level lässt man jedoch das eine oder andere Nebenlevel liegen, was dann nach dem Abspann noch gespielt werden kann. Darüber hinaus gibt es eine Vielzahl an geheimen Leveln und versteckten Features und auch das Fähigkeiten- und Itemsystem animiert zum weiteren Erkunden. Dabei kann jedes Level so oft wiederholt werden, wie man möchte. Für höhere XP-Ausbeute kann die Schwierigkeit fast unbegrenzt erhöht werden. Die Langzeitmotivation leidet unter dem Fehlen einer Obergrenze bei Attributen. So levelt man seine Fähigkeiten höher, nur um die Level noch schwieriger stellen zu können. Es fehlt ein wirkliches Ziel. Problem hierbei vor allem: Um bei meinem Level noch eine Herausforderung zu haben muss man sehr viele Monster spawnen lassen. Dies führt auf auf Gaming-Hardware der neuesten Generation zu unerträglichen Lags.

[u]Fazit:[/u]
[i]Pro:[/i]
-	Einmalig-geniale Spielmechanik
-	Viel Freiheit beim Spielverlauf
-	Langzeitmotivation für dreistellige Spielstundenzahl

[i]Kontra: [/i]
-	Lags bei hoher Monsterzahl
-	Nach Erreichen eines sehr hohen Levels stark abfallende Motivation

[b]-->	Bestes Towerdefence-Spiel auf dem Markt[/b]

20260163.review:
Gemcraft:CS is a great tower defense game, lot of content and lot of variety. It's about gems, of course, you spend mana (which also represents your life bar) to conjure more and more powerful gems in any combination of 9 flavours, each one bringing a different special ability to the final product. Then you socket these gems into stationary assets you build on the field, such as towers, traps, and amplifiers. And then, in time, you'll unlock three area-of-effect spells and three gem enchantments, all on separate cooldown. And then you'll get talisman fragments to randomly drop, and will socket and upgrade up to 15 of them into a large panel, securing a number of additional bonuses and perks. And then you'll gather xp at the end of every mission and invest them in the 25 skills available, or stash them in order to get a different kind of bonus. And then you'll move up and unlock all of the 150+ battlefields available, up to the Spiritforge. And then you'll want to try vision battlefields, where skills and talismans and all that stuff don't matter and you're alone and scared like the first time. And then you'll want to try Iron Wizard mode, with different rules to the game. And that's just scratching the surface.

On top of all that, you can drastically personalize the level of challenge: each battlefield can be played in one of three different difficulty settings, and up to 9 crippling traits can be enabled to different extents in order to make the game more engaging/unforgiving. And even then, you can increase the challenge dynamically by calling in waves ahead of time and even 'enrage' them, which is to say 'spend mana to increase number, healthpool and armor of foes in a wave'.

This little gem (hah) has a lot going for it, so if in doubt, trust a random stranger on the interwebs and buy this game!

20252786.review:
I picked this up expecting nothing much, I don't even like tower defense games, but I got a lot more than I expected. This is really a pretty engaging and fun game with more options and more involved gameplay than even the trailer makes it seem (unfortunately not a very great endorsement for the game there.) You have six types of structure, nine types of gem, and every gem types can be mixed together to produce different types beyond the basic ones across several levels of gem strength which all adds onto map positioning, bombings (just throwing gems at things instead of socketing them), enraging waves, early calls, and other mechanics. I expected a pretty dull time waster but Gemcraft put a lot of tools on the table here and made every new map feel different than the last and a fun challenge to find out how to make sure you survive past the last wave...

And then you can even hit a button when you finish for a no risk continuation of infinite waves to see how well your setup actually would fare past what it needed to which usually results in a horrible failure 15 minutes into but awards you with extra experience for the effort. Oh and did I mention the skills, spells, and talisman systems? Those are nifty too. The game even rewards you for NOT spending experience so just about everything is a choice you're making between one of several options, even deciding to spend experience. 

This isn't a perfect game but it's a pretty fucking good one. The graphics are really poor, Flash is still Flash, and you'll have heard your fill of sound effects and music in the first few hours easily but what it does do it does it too well to dock it too much for that. It's MUCH better than the cost would lead you to believe too so give it a shot.

20215223.review:
A tower defense game with deep RPG elements and lots of replayability. The more you play the more you can do with the game. The traits and difficulty system keep old levels fresh as they keep the levels harder and harder giving you massive XP rewards and better talismans, to replay other levels with (rather) same difficulty setting ad nauseum.

Pros:
- Good graphics
- Lots of replay value
- Lots of levels to play through (190+ levels)
- Lots of mechanics (summoning, 9 adjustable traits)
- Vision fields to test players true strategy skills
- Level exclusive achievements to push players to the limit, strategy and/or strength wise
- Steam exclusive levels

Cons:
- Most levels can be done with one tower (even from the start, normal mode)
- End-game grinding causes lags
- Constant HUD freeze can be frustrating at times

You can play the flash version for free just to check whether you should buy this game or not at Armor Games, but if you like tower defense games, you should buy it, even if you're a casual player.

20215066.review:
バンドルでの購入でしたが思いの外楽しかったのでレビュー。
17時間/24フィールドクリアした状態です(おそらくまだ序盤)。

タワーディフェンス系はほとんどプレーしたことがありませんので細かく比較はできませんが、マップごとに都度 Gem(宝石) を作成する形なので特定のキャラクターを育てる楽しみはありませんが、逆に苦労して育ててきたキャラクターを失う恐れもありません。
では成長要素がないかというとそうでもなく、たまに拾えるアイテムによる強化や、実績をとることで得られるポイントを使って強化、などがあります。これもほぼ再振り分け可能です。ということでマップごとに気楽に遊べると思います。

マップを進めていくことにより追加要素が増えていきますが親切なガイド表示もあり、また、マップに対するテーマ的なもの(クリアすると大抵この実績が得られる)があったりもするのでルール的に困ることはほぼないと思います。

マップを経るごとに追加要素はあるものの大筋としては同じわけで、あまり根を詰めてやるようなゲームでもないと思いますので、他のゲームの息抜きがてらにでもちょこちょこ進める、実績を集める(419もあります)、という遊び方が適したゲームではないかと思います。

バンドル分の元はこれ1本で十分取れたと思います。セール中であれば購入して損はないのではないでしょうか？

This one, is very simplistic at first glance.

- upgrades gems to do more damage
- rinse and repeat

20155896.review:
This is the best tower defense game I have ever played, and I really think that 'GemCraft - Chasing Shadows' is the best tower defense game on steam. The game benefits from it's gem system, allowing you to combine your tower properties and upgrade your towers to have multiple abilities. The learning curve for this game is smooth, with only a few spikes that grab your attention to the hints on the maps that help tower noobies to learn how to take advantage of your starting materials and the environment. 

Gemcraft also features RPG elements such as a leveling system along with skills and equipable fragments for the tailsman, allowing you to gain an advantage in levels that were previously too difficult to complete (this means that you can grind to help you progress through the game if you'd like). If you think that grinding might make the game too easy, there are additional handicaps that the player can set on themselves to give more EXP and shadow cores for upgrading fragments. Achievements in the game are plenty and serve as milestones, giving the player skill points as a reward and keeping the difficult of the game from becoming to troublesome at later points in the game. 

Gemcraft is a huge game for a tower defense game, which is incredible since the entire game can be played on the web for free at ArmorGames. I really encourage anyone who wants to play a tower defense game to try GemCraft, it doesn't get any better than this.

19932479.review:
GemCraft - Chasing Shadows is an outstanding tower defense game that's one of the more stimulating ways to kill time.
The main gimmick of this series is that your towers are sockets for gems, which are the source of your attacks and can be switched between towers as well as fused to combine their special effects.

The game has very complex mechanics, but it doesn't feel overwhelming as they're introduced one by one and many are optional. It's a lot of fun to get accustomed to new abilities or structures, and the game is only punishing if you want it to be.
Aside from common features such as custom targeting, fast-forward (up to 9x), mazing and calling waves early, there's many unique concepts, lots of different structures to keep things diverse, and the ideas from previous GemCraft games have been vastly improved.
Slightly annoying: demolitions are costly and limited even in the preparation phase, so if you make a mistake with wall building you may have to restart and build everything again.
Chasing Shadows' main problem is that it runs on Flash, so there's no linux support. For a flash game it runs well though, lag is only an issue at extremely high levels.
There's a lot of content. The large amount of maps is supplemented by custom difficulty modifiers and the option to continue each level in endless mode. On sale, the amount of playtime you get for 2€ is just ridiculous.

19865907.review:
Very polished game. 191 different, unique maps. Great sound design, gives a feeling of oppression. You get stronger by clearing areas, and you can get more by re-visiting them and getting a better score. You are in control of the difficulty and there are various ways to adjust that, before and during the fight. This means you cannot get stuck, as eventually you'll be able to win by pure brute force. And once you start doing survival mode farming techniques, you discover that there is no level cap.

Then there's the huge list of achievements. Awesome. And they're also tracked ingame separately for each individual save, which boosts replayability. Also, Iron Wizard mode for a simplified but much more challenging playthrough.

Try the previous chapters too if you liked this and want more. They're flash games playable for free in the browser. They have somewhat different rules and much less polish, but the feel is the same.

19725092.review:
Prepare to be addicted!  

A tower defense game with a dark, gritty atmosphere and tons of choices for upgrading skills, choosing which types of gems you prefer to use, as well as extra stuff like spells, shrines, etc.   A map that lets you choose your path, and even replay levels to your hearts content.   And best of all, tons of achievments that actually give you in-game bonus points to use in upgrading your skills.  Finally, we achievment hunters can have a legitimate reason for getting achievements!

Now I must warn you that I have not completed the game yet.  But 20 hours in and I haven't seen anything to change my mind that this game is highly reccommended.  

Ok, so this is tower defense.  You build towers (traps, too!) and hope that they kill off the incoming line of enemies.  Only in this game the towers are powered by gems.  Each color does something different.  The green poison gem is my current favorite.  The red chain hit one is good too.  There's gems that steal mana from the enemy, deplete enemy armor, prevent enemies from regenerating their health, and more.  

Gems are created with mana.  You start with some mana but also gain mana slowly and by killing enemies.  Use the mana to create more gems or upgrade your existing gems to higher levels.  You can have gems from levels 1-12, but so far I have only been able to afford up to level 8.  Each level costs more than the previous level to create a gem.  You can also move gems around, but there is a short wait time for the gem to socket before it can start attacking.   Gems can also be used to bomb enemies with wasp stings, but I haven't found that very effective.  

Each time  you complete a level it unlocks one or more new levels.  Map sections are hexogonal and eventually it opens up two pathway options.  So the game is not completely linear, which I love.  You gain experience and also get shadow cores to use to upgrade your abilities.  

There is so much customization in this game, so you can play it in your own style.  You can redistribute your ability points any time you want, so you're not stuck with your upgrades.  Or you can spend the shadow cores to increase your chance of getting better loot and rare items.  The maps have quite a variety of pathways.   And you can build little walls to make a maze to slow the monsters down.

Graphics are seen from a top down angle, and the most realistic looking graphics that I've seen in a tower defense game, though I haven't seen them all.  Most of the games in this genre seem to be cartoon-like, but this game has lush forests, stone pathways, and dark insect-looking monsters!

Music is more of a kind of ethereal chorus or extended chords.  Not a tune.  But it's perfect for this game.  It really adds to the monstrous ambiance.

Replay value is huge.  As far as I know you can replay levels as much as you want, to grind for experience and to get the hard achievements.    But like I said, I haven't finished it yet so I dont' know if there might be a reason not to take too much time.

Controls are done with the mouse and there are keyboard shortcuts.

Story-wise, there are sometimes pages that tell the story but mostly it's just killing monsters.  Maybe there's more story later on, I dont' know.  This game won't appeal to someone who just wants to play once through a game.  It's for people who like to do the same thing over and over again.  I like to challenge myself to use the least amount of mana and still make it through the level, and stuff like that.  So, if that sounds like you, then buy this game without waiting!  It is well worth the price.  No need to wait for a sale.  

The only bad thing is I'm neglecting my other games to play this one.  My poor backlog!

Update:  I forgot to mention that there is blood but no gore.  And there's a setting where you can turn off the blood if you want.

19560764.review:
I have always liked the GemCraft series, since I first discovered it as free Flash Games on Armor Games.
All of the entries to the franchise are tower defense games, that successively paid more and more attention to building up content and refining game mechanics.

There is a story to the game, which frankly feels like it has been put there to just not have no story, but these kind of games really can do without a thrilling plot - even more so since the gameplay changes feel like a success to me. And that is kinda the important part: Even though I highly consider myself a person that doesn't like change, I was familiarizing really quick with the new elements and wouldn't want to go back. The new additions make the game more customizable as ever before, so you can play your own style of game and still succeed more than likely.

I already put above 30 hours into the game and it still doesn't look like I have come close anywhere near the end. Up until the point where I am, maps also don't seem repetitive to me and coming back for them, when you acquired new gear or skills can make them feel totally different again.

My only con to the game is the performance which sometimes (even on waves around 100) can go down, especially after casting certain spells. I feel like it's a limitation of the engine they used, I don't think it's my system :]

In conclusion: If you like crafty games, where you can choose your own methods and if you enjoyed any of the predecessors or similiar games from the tower/lane defense genres (like "Orcs Must Die!" or "Plants vs. Zombies"), then do yourself a favor and pick this gem up.

In the course of 2016's Steam Autumn sale I nominate this game for the "Just 5 More Minutes" Award, because of how addictive and long-lasting the challenge of this game is.

Sempre acompanhei os GemCrafts lançados na era do flash ainda, e simplesmente é o melhor Tower Defense que já joguei! E olha que já joguei muitos por não ter um PC muito avantajado na época. E agora vou recitar o que eu pensei quando eu abri o primeiro jogo:
-Que joguinho zoado, vou jogar uma partida só pra ver.
-Beleza, terminei, deixa eu jogar outra partida.
-Consegui! Vamos a próxima.
-Boa, joguei bem. Opa, liberei skill nova? Vamos testar.
-Pô, essa skill deixou muito mais desafiador, gostei.

Tive esse mesmo pensamento quando comprei na Steam, só que troca o "joguinho zoado" por "Opa, GemCraft", o resto não muda.
E assim você continua pelas próximas dúzias de horas.


Sobre a análise do jogo:
Prós:
Jogo MUITO grande comparados a outros jogos do tipo. Você talvez levará mais de 20 horas para finalizá-lo completamente.
Há muitos desafios em um mesmo mapa como deixar mais difícil, fazer com que sumone mais gigantes, ter mana recuperada somente a cada x segundos, etc.
O jogo inteiro é bem sombrio, te envolve bastante no gameplay.
Não notei nenhuma queda de desempenho, com todos os gráficos ao máximo.

Contras:
O jogo é simples, não há muitos detalhes gráficos e nem muita definição neles, eles somente pegaram o .swf (formato flash) e transformaram para .exe.
O jogo vai aumentando a dificuldade constantemente te obrigando a voltar em missões já feitas para conseguir XP e melhorar alguma skil. (Tudo bem, parece normal, muitos outros jogos fazem isso. Mas pelo menos nesse GemCraft, a dificuldade vai aumentando tanto que às vezes perco a vontade de jogar)
O jogo não possui outras formas de jogar, é simplesmente construir a torre, construir a gema, colocar a gema na torre e defender sua orb. Não que isso seja totalmente ruim, mas poderia ter algo diferente.

Agora estou esperando aí que nesse 2016 eu perca o BV e que lance outro GemCraft, mas totalmente para a Steam. Com gráficos mais definidos e muitos outros modos para jogar. Se tiver isso, tenho certeza que ultrapassaremos 50hrs de jogo.

19324022.review:
A updated look at one of the most popular web-based tower defense titles.  Solid, but standard pathing, construction, and other elements found in many other titles; the main features here are the RPG progression, and the use of 'gems' to power towers, traps, and other attacks.

Gems can be summoned for mana, combined to support multiple effects, leveled up for increased effectiveness, and even dropped from the heavens.  Dropped gems' power are based on their level, and can be used as bombs, to power up friendly structures, or even to power up enemy waves for higher challenge and reward.

It's a great concept, and it makes for one of the deepest offerings you'll find in the genre when combined with the skill tree, branching map, and countless modifiers to customize your play.  On top of that, GemCraft features an absolutely watertight theme, carrying a grim and sombre dark-fantasy tale.

An instant classic.

19230574.review:
Gemcraft CS is one of the best, if not the best, tower defense game on Steam. It is a straight to the point, massive re-playable game. Your role is to combine gems with varieties, in order to kill a specific monster wave count at every stage. There are two modes, a normal very adjustable one and a difficult, more fixed one.

The breakthrough in my opinion is that the difficulty of every stage is adjustable to the players’ skill/likeness, by added traits in battle. As you gain levels and level up you get skill points to boost your skills and talisman fragments that raise your stats. Furthermore the enemy level and number is also adjustable, making the whole game suitable for any type of player, casual or hardcore. There are also a massive number of playing fields (some hidden, some as puzzle rewards).

Great game overall, well crafted, balanced, with option giving gameplay.

18719060.review:
I am a big fan of Tower Defense games, and I can say without a doubt this is the best one I've ever played.

First, there is a ton of content. over 190 levels, with most of them having 3 difficulties + an endurance mode are sure to keep you busy for hours and hours.

Second, the gameplay. While this is a tower defense game, there are some RPG alements mixed in, and as you clear fields you gain levels and skill points, which form a satisfying progression that can be felt heavily in the game. Playing the game itself is also a breeze, thatnks to the fact that practically everything is keybound and you can pause the game to take action.

Third, the difficulty. The difficulty in this game is heavily scalable. In addition to the 3 difficulty modes, you can set battle traits to increase things like enemy health and get more xp out of it. It's a high-risk, high-reward system that works very well.

Also, the game has a nice story, even if you haven't played the previous games on the series.

Well, Well, Well. Gemcraft you have become an Executable, and a £4.99 executable at that, which for many of the series followers is a giant betrayal, i am a game designer with a degree in Games Design so i can understand why they made it a pay only game unlike all 4 or 5 previous gemcraft games which By the way if im doing a review im going to be brutally honest. 

Gameplay - well rest assured this game lives up to the previous Gemcraft games being the next in the series with the story following the same format as the previous games, the evil darkness is trying to get hold of your spirit forge and you need to stop her (i say her, because it clearly states the "Evil shadows" are female [possible spoiler]). 

game play is very similar to the other games however the biggest difference is there are now 2 new gems, the Black and the White, although the previous games didnt have these gem colours their effects were in the games, if i can remember correctly the Black gem is what the Red gem used to be it will get more powerfull the more it hits an enemy, and the white Gem gets more powerfull the more you upgrade your manapool. i will say that the previous gemcraft game gemcraft the labrinth was amazing, and if "game in a bottle" make a new game similar and make it cost £4.99 then it should damn well succeed where the others didnt, the map should be  2 or 3 times bigger with more to do on each level. 
although there is alot to do in each level theres not as many levels or at least it doesnt feel as if there is. The world map is a grid sytem each tile on the grid is a letter of the alphabet with probably 4 maybe 5 levels in each tile, so there are a lot of levels which is good :) but... for a game that used to be a flash game on the internet i was expecting alot more from an executable that now costs £4.99.

All in all Still the best Tower Deffence Game out there im just dissapointed that there wasnt more new content that the other free games already did.

Verdict -  The game is still very good and i still play it even though ive completed all levels, if you cant bring yourself to pay for the game my advice is go online and play gemcraft: Labrinth for free then if you like that one finish it and buy this new one. it is still worth it, and you never know they might rectify the price sometime down the line :)

18132772.review:
I'm writing this late review out of gratitude to the developer and because I believe this game deserves another positive review. This game is THE defining Tower Defense game. Every other I've played has come nowhere to the enjoyment I felt playing this. 

You want replayability? The game essentially never ends. You can beat the final map but you can always do better, or unlock new maps. Or replay older maps to beat it at a higher difficulty to level up.

You want customisation? This game has it. Lots of it. Play the game how YOU want, how YOU would enjoy it. Sure, at high level there are common strategies used by most but the game lets you choose alternative ways if you care more about having fun than constantly beating your past exp score.

And speaking of fun, yes, this game has all of it. 

My one criticism is - believe it or not - that this game is TOO good. I worry that the sequel (and there WILL be a sequel to this amazing game) won't have anywhere near the amount to expand and improve upon that this one did. But I should really have more faith in the developer than that, as they have proved how much of a good game they can already make.

18034952.review:
Having played the online light version on Armor Games, I have decided to buy the full in house Steam version of this game. If you like solving tasks and shooting evil monsters for kicks. This game is great fun to play and I really enjoy playing through the levels at will and while the levels are quite easy at first. This is deliberate, so that you are settled into the game before moving onto the much more tougher levels.

The Objectives:
This can vary from level to level. But in order to successfully pass the level. It is imperitive that you keep your orb intact and to protect from banishment from the monsters because if the mana pool reaches zero or a lower number than the banishment cost from the monster and the monster touches the orb in this state. Its Game Over and you would need to start the level again. While this is not going to be an issue in the early levels as these levels have a lower waves of monsters, you will find this more challenging in the later levels that have tougher enemies and more waves of monsters that you must defeat in order to complete the level. Its doesn't stop there however because some levels have tome chambers that will have to opened by meeting certain criterias to unlock vital skills and also you will still need to survive all enemy waves to complete the level AND to gain the skill from the tome chamber.

Mana:
The Mana bar is your lifeline as it used to buy gems, build buildings and traps as well as to sustain banishment charges from those monsters that are successful in banishing your orb. Careful planning and conservative use of the mana in levels will gain you extra mana to use at the start of other levels. So its wise to conserve as much mana as you can muster in early levels. This is a method that I learned the hard way when I was playing the light version of this game online. 

My thoughts:
If you are into tactical games like I am and want to challenge yourself. Give this game a try as you will need to use your tactical skills to conquer the more harder levels and you may need to replay some levels to give you more mana for the later levels so that you can buy more powerful gems at the start. Even things like the placement of a tower on the level to the strength of a gem can mean the difference of success or failure.

Verdict:
The key thing to have with this tactical game is PATIENCE and planning. If you rush through the early levels without giving much thought to points that I have mentioned. Then the later levels could be frustrating to some players if they do not plan their motives carefully. Patience and tactics are the road to completion of this game.

Overall Rating: 10/10.

17983817.review:
So, what is there to say about this game that hasn't already been said (especially the review by Genoce)? Well, not that much. I mean, it's not a TD game for everyone, that I will admit. With 190 levels, a gazillion ways to tweak skills and difficulty settings, and the way to combine gems to create just what you want, it does have a higher treshold of entry than most such games. But if it does get its hooks in you, then wave goodbye to the next 100+ hours or so of your gaming schedule. And so this review should pretty much end.

However, I'd like to also respond to some of the negative criticisms in the game, which is going to take up a lot more space:

[b]"It's too random, what with the specters and shadows."[/b]
While it's technically true that these add an element of uncertainty, it's not that random (for one thing, you get warnings beforehand that it's about to happen), and it's therefore most certainly possible to plan for it. In fact, once you know how to deal with those things, then even if a shadow show up on wave 5, they'll never be a problem. And personally, the levels I've felt where randomness was more of an issue are the special Vision levels, because they're meant to be tight fights at all times. Sometimes they're so tight, that if your gems in the first wave tends to end up doing minimum damage shots, you've already lost. Then the next time you try said gems shoot maximum damage, and you survive and move on to clear the whole damn level.

Aside from that, I've hardly ever played any TD game that is -less- random than this game (maybe the previous games in the series, but they too had it, if in different forms)! For one thing, like I said, the difficulty setting is completely and utterly under your control, and never feels arbitrary. Take Kingdom Rush in comparison; the game's later mission levels on that game requires a lot of planning -and- early wave luck (i.e. good damage on the first few hits)... And that was on casual difficulty. Normal and Difficult requires nothing less than utter perfection in every single detail there. And Cursed Treasure 2 has levels entirely depending on early mana flask drops if you want three stars. This game, mana flow is forever something you can do something about, and you have a lot more freedom in placing your towers. There's nothing happening in this game that you cannot react to (except the aforementioned low-damage early shots in the vision fields).

Oh, and it seems like the amount of Shadows appearing has been severely downgraded compared to earlier versions of the game. I'm currently 

[b]"It is too grindy, especially if you want a complete game."[/b]
Well... Yes. It's true. I mean, if you know what you're doing, you can sweep through the main levels doing them all only one time each, and the Vision levels are completely set in terms of what gems and spells you have, so obviously any amount of grinding won't help you beat them. But if you want a complete game, you'll have to replay levels, yes. And yes, the levels are pretty long too, because this game is about making a set-up.

...Which is something you do in every TD game that's worth a damn anyway. And at least if you want to grind here, you have to be clever about it, since it will always only be the highest score you get in any given level that counts. Also, don't forget Gemcraft Chapter 0. If you wanted a complete game there (i.e. each level completely shining), you had to replay every level 8 times. 8. Frickin'. Times. Here, you can get away with twice each (once on Looming and once on Haunting difficulty, ignoring Glaring), and if you unlock Haunting early, a fair few can be beaten with only one attempt.

[b]"There's barely any mazing."[/b]
Again, pretty much true. You don't spend that much time setting up walls to lead the monsters exactly where you want... And that is a bloody good thing too, because every TD I've played that's required excessive mazing on every level are immensely boring; with the fields usually being mainly empty except for a few ocstables that prevents you from optimal mazing every time. Who needs that crap? I sure don't.

[b]"Once you find the optimal strategy, it's nothing else to do."[/b]
Again true (I sense a pattern here)... And I'm not going to defend this per se, except saying that in the Gemcraft series as a whole, much of the point is about figuring out how to exploit everything. And I personally -like- games that gives you the option of doing that, provided they make sure that (barring going online and looking up other people's work) it's a challenge to find out how to exploit it. And this game's got that challenge. Way back when I first played this on AG, I thought I had a pretty good deal going on with the things I'd made up... and then I read about how other people had found stuff that put my strategies to utter shame (though they had the Magician's Pouch; I hadn't. I still wouldn't have figured out that other stuff in a million years, though). 

Still, my non-Magician Pouch based strategy was good enough for me to then beat field O6 at Wizard Level 56. Others had problems with that field 30 or more wizard levels above mine, so that was nice. :D

Anyway, as you can see, I'm not always disagreeing with these criticisms, and you as a buyer should take them into consideration, as that this is a very, very specialised Tower Defense game. But I certainly like it, and since it is available to try out for free on several flash game websites, you'll have the opportunity to try it out for yourself. And I think you should. ;)

This game is all about options, because with a little experience you can earn mutators to be set pre mission to increase the difficulty and the XP earned. You can also pour your power (through gems,) into the oncoming monster waves, to toughen them and earn you more XP.

You also can find drops of talismans for more upgrades, and these can be improved. 

If you like tower defense games, this is a no brainer, up there with Defense Grid and Defender's Quest.

■概要
アレンジメントのバリエーションが非常に豊富な ”ジェム”  で
敵を攻撃するタワーディフェンス。
いくらか制約はあるものの、ある程度プレイヤーが迷路を作成でき、
タワーの設置自由度も非常に高く、ストラテジー要素が強いゲーム。

■ゲームプレイ
本作の特徴はやはりタイトルに有る ”craft” 要素だろう。
他のタワーディフェンスではちょっと見られないシステムで、
プレイヤーの関与できるシステムをぐっと広げてくれる。

”craft” の文字通り、敵を攻撃するジェムはプレイヤーが作成する。
まず全9色のジェムから一つを選択、次にジェムのレベルを決め作成。
このジェムをマップに設置すると、色に応じた特殊能力を持つ攻撃を、
敵に対して自動で行ってくれる、いわゆる「タワー」となる。

本ゲームはここからが本番。ジェムは複数個同士の合成が可能で、
合成によって得られたジェムは合成前のジェムの特徴を引き継ぐ。
これによって、「複数の敵への攻撃」ができ、「毒の効果」をもち、
さらに「クリティカル発生確率」を持つなどマルチな能力を持った
スペシャルなジェムを作成することができる。
特筆すべきはジェムのバリエーションで、
色は全9色、レベルは1から12まであるので、これだけで108種類。
さらにそれを何個でも合成でき、出来上がるジェムの種類は無数。
（実際は12を超えて30、40とレベルを上げることができる）

他にもプレイヤーが関与すべきシステムは多数あり、
まずはアクションスキルとパッシブスキルの存在がある。
特にパッシブスキルに至ってはスキルポイントを割り振ることで
段階的に強化でき、なんとスキルレベルの上限値が無い。
これによりプレイヤー好みの戦術を強力に後押しすることが可能。
リスペックも一切の制限が無く可能で、
極端な例ではマップ毎にスキルを完全に入れ替えることも容易。
他にもランダムな性能を持ったタリスマンと呼ばれる装備品もあり、
こちらでも戦術面へ影響を与えることができる。

■総合
とにかくプレイヤーがあれこれ戦術を練ることができる。
プレイヤーのcraft結果が攻撃力となってダイレクトに明示される為
「自分自身が戦場をコントロール」している感覚が非常に強い。
体力が高くシールドを持った敵に特化したジェムを作成するも良し、
足の速い敵に対応するためのジェムと併用するも良し、
攻撃はしないが周囲のタワーを強化するアンプを大量に建てるも良しで
「プレイヤーが頭を悩ませる楽しさ」を刺激してくれる。

以上のようにシステムが豊富で取っ付き難い感があるかもしれないが、
チュートリアルやヘルプのポップアップが親切なので
順に学びながらプレイしていける作りとなっており親切。

敵はエイリアンや虫のような異形の生物がカサカサ動き、
タワーは固形のGemである為に、美しさやアクションが無く
見た目を楽しめるものではないので注意。

マップ数は100を優に超え、難易度も3段階あるので
全て制覇するには数十時間では到底及ばない程のボリュームがあり
本作一本でじっくりと時間をかけて遊ぶことができる。

総じてお勧め。
（2015/8/13）

17166475.review:
Fun initially, but becomes posesses exactly the wrong mixture of insanely hard puzzles plus a brain-numbing grinding. 190 levels... and to "finish" the game you have to complete all of them three times?! Not counting the special playthroughs you'll need to do to get meet goals that give you more skillpoints. All the levels require the same strategy, ultimately - build a tower near your orb, surround it with amps, and push the "u" key constantly for a hundred waves or so.

This would almost be a good game for casual players, since the main levels are so easy. But there are one or two levels that are so ridiculously hard that they seem impossible even in theory. Avoid this game if you don't like the idea of spending several hundred hours breezing through levels with the exact same strategy, then banging your head against the wall for ten hours trying to beat one of the "special" challenges.

17149692.review:
Pros:
+ Very engaging for a tower defense game. You have an assortment of spells that you must use to counteract sudden bursts of strong enemies, which keeps you on your toes. Unlocking new skills requires smart use of these spells.
+ Huge amount of content, with nearly 200 maps.
+ Very atmospheric with creepy graphical effects. When the antagonist starts showing up, the game actually gets quite scary without ever relying on jump scares. 

Neutral:
o Lots of grinding. If you like power leveling your characters in RPGs, this will be a pro for you.
o The game isn't inherently challenging. You have to set up your own mix of difficulty options to match your current level and find a sweet spot.

Negative:
- Hilarious balancing issues. A strong yellow-white dual gem will have over a million DPS, whereas all other gem types usually only have a couple thousand. Monsters can heal over time, but even bosses only regenerate like 15.000 HP per minute. Your one million DPS uber gem will laugh at this, and gems that cancel out those healing powers are oboslete. A strong poison gem in a trap will deal about 7.000 HP of poison damage over time to every monster it hits - not quite so useful when even the swarmer type enemies have 150.000 HP each.
- Higher difficulties hardly strengthen the first wave of enemies, but the rate at which waves get stronger increases dramatically. You could beat wave 60 without any effort, but then get stomped by wave 80 on the same map. This means that you'll just be sitting there for 20 minutes to then see if you can beat the final few waves.
- If you use the Chasing Shadows mod, there's huge reliance on RNG. If a Shadow shows up early, its armor is so thick that you cannot damage it and you just die. This adds nothing to the game, it just means that you have to restart the map until no Shadows show up for the first 5-10 waves.

In the end, the pros still outweigh the cons, especially because most of these flaws are related to high-level play and will not be relevant to you before you've already more than gotten your money's worth out of this game. It's still one of the most entertaining tower defense games I have ever played.

17020797.review:
A Kongregate classic churned into a stat grinder tower defense game? Awesome.

Gameplay: 9/10

+ Iron Wizard mode, in case you want classic Gemcraft back.
+ Destroying 999 monsters on a wave is pretty damn satisfying.
+ 2 new gem types to experiment with
+ Leveling system
+ Amulet system
+ 190 levels. Wat
+ CC Spells and tower buffs
- Can be repetitive once you begin the Endurance meta
- Certain gem types become obsolete in the meta

Story: 7/10

= Meh
+ Cool concepts
+ Nice atmosphere and visuals
- Lack of depth
= So-so ending: Reeks of setup for a sequel  (Which isn't bad I suppose)

Technical: 8/10

+ Game runs very well
+ Low PC requirements
+ Graphics options just in case
+ Very little to no bugs
- Can tax your PC if it's not prepared for processing thousands of entities on-screen
- No button hotkey customization

Visual: 9/10

+ Thanks Shadows for being scary as hell
+ Graphically superior to the older games
+ Dozens of gems firing off at once can be visually appealing
+++ Gems. Dazzling. Fabulous.
+ Rendering thousands of monsters as they struggle to crush your orb, and then annihilating them.

Overall: 8.25/10

TL;DR Great game. Highly recommended TD game for all.

17006622.review: This is a tower defence game where you customize the tower by the gems you create. The gems can have their power increased from leveling them, and gems of different types can be mixed together (if they are the same level it will increase the level as well). The main difference I noticed about this game is that you can use the gems you craft to "enrage" upcoming waves to increase the number of enemies that come in it and increase the toughness of each unit in the wave. For the higher difficulties you need to balance the amount of gems you enrage upcoming waves with, and the amount of mana you spent to upgrade the gems to help kill the incoming enemies. The game allows you even more customization by giving you skill points that can be used to provide a global buff to your gems, or otherwise help you to defend yourself. There's a just a lot of depth, and its an enjoyable experience to play. Well worth the price point :).

16992283.review:
Good game but not a tower defence game. You build a couple (1-3) towers, upgrade it and, nothing else. The rest of the game is spreadsheet work. Tower types are boring - tower types only differ in how they do damage. There's barely any mazing (you have to build walls, like, 2-3 of them every few maps, but that's it) because most paths are still narrow. There's barely any need to think about coverage/good positioning, because as mentioned earlier you build only a few of them (sometimes even 1) and towers shoot so fast you don't need to think about mobs of weak enemies vs single strong enemy.

The main depth of the game is in the numerical works, if you're into it. There are only 3 different type of mobs - small medium and large. They differ in armor, regen, may be some extra wacky special but can be summarized as "tanky stats". Your tower is pretty much the same, hit armor, hit regen, crit, etc just different way to deal damage. Then there are talismans, which are small bonuses to your damage, mana etc and skills, which allow you to build tower cheapers, deal more damage etc So basically A LOT of numbers and your goal is to balance them until you win. 

So I suppose it's probably fun for people who enjoy a lot of spreadsheet works. But it's not tower defense.

16984487.review:
I am flabberghasted at how awesome this game is. Ridiculus amounts of content and depth for a "simple" tower defense game and at a decent price. I have absolutely nothing but warm recommendations for this game. But, in the interest of diversity, I will mention a fair few flaws or gripes.

The game runs on Flash via Air. This means there's no hope of running this natively on Linux as it stands. It also means it will lag like crazy when you get to wizard levels 1000 and above and you really start to abuse the enrage mechanic and get thousands of monsters on screen at once. For simple story mode or casual play, you'll never notice. But if you're hardcore, lag will become a factor eventually.

It also means that the entire client will bog down and not respond to inputs as the game lags, this can make controlling the game hard when there's a bajillion things going on at once. Remember to pause your game before issuing commands if you are going into those deep-enrage endurance games.

The story is about as throwaway as it gets. It gets unraveled as you play and is presented in chunks of text with some basic (but neat) artwork. It's a continuation of a series, so unless you played the previous games, the story may seem a bit disjointed but I feel the devs made a good effort to "fill you in" even if you missed the first three. 

Otherwise I have nothing but positives for the game. I absolutely detest the tower defense genre. Nothing but uncreative, pretty, cow-clicky games with zero depth and no strategy. They all end up having one super awesome strategy that always works, or having only one solution per level.  Gemcraft though? Totally breaks the mold and makes even a hater love it. That's the warmest recommendations I can ever give a game.
